revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = A Dark Room |image = A dark room logo.jpg |developer = Doublespeak Games, Amir Rajan (iOS) |publisher = Doublespeak Games, Circle Entertainment (Switch) |director = |designer = Michael Townsend |composer = |engine = |released = 2013 |genre = [[Online text-based role-playing game]]
[[Incremental game]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = {{Plainlist| * [[Internet browser]] * [[Android (operating system)|Android]] * [[iOS]] * [[Nintendo Switch]]}} }} '''''A Dark Room''''' is an [[open-source software]] [[Online text-based role-playing game|role-playing text-based game]] originally published in mid-2013 for [[web browsers]] by Canadian indie studio Doublespeak Games. Later that year, it was released in the [[IOS App Store|App Store]] for [[iOS]] devices. In 2014, a prequel entitled ''[[The Ensign (video game)|The Ensign]]'', which provided more insight into the world and its characters, was released for iOS. ==Production== ''A Dark Room'' was created by Michael Townsend and released for [[Web browser|browsers]] on June 10, 2013.{{cite web|title=A Dark Room released|url=http://blog.doublespeakgames.com/games/a-dark-room-released/|publisher=Doublespeak Games|accessdate=19 October 2015}} According to Townsend, the game was designed to tell its story entirely through environmental cues, rather than relying on exposition and dialogue.{{cite web |last=Thomsen |first=Michael |url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/elements/2014/06/a-dark-room-the-best-selling-game-that-no-one-can-explain.html |title=A Dark Room: The Best-Selling Game That No One Can Explain |publisher=[[The New Yorker]] |date= |accessdate=2014-07-14 |quote=''Townsend was happy to share his work with Rajan. "I want to kindle the creative spirit in others," Townsend told me over e-mail. "My games are open-source because I want people to learn from them, or use them to build their own things."''}} In July 2013, Townsend released the [[source code]] of the game on [[GitHub]] under the [[open source license]] [[Mozilla Public License|MPL]] 2.0.{{cite web|title=A Dark Room goes open source|url=http://blog.doublespeakgames.com/news/a-dark-room-goes-open-source/|publisher=Doublespeak Games|accessdate=19 October 2015}} Soon, Townsend was contacted by developer [[Amirali Rajan|Amir Rajan]], who asked for permission to adapt the game for [[iOS]].{{cite web|title=A Dark Room on iOS|url=http://blog.doublespeakgames.com/games/a-dark-room-on-ios/|publisher=Doublespeak Games|accessdate=19 October 2015}} Amir ported the game to iOS using the [[RubyMotion]] mobile toolchain,{{cite web|url=http://www.rubymotion.com/references/success-stories/a-dark-room |title=RubyMotion Success Story: A Dark Room |publisher=RubyMotion Blog |date= |accessdate=2014-04-08}} and released it on the App Store in late 2013. From 2014 onwards an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[Porting|port]] of ''A Dark Room'' was being worked on, which was finally released in 2016.[http://blog.doublespeakgames.com/news/a-dark-room-android-entering-private-beta/ a-dark-room-android-entering-private-beta]{{cite web|url=http://blog.doublespeakgames.com/games/a-dark-room-is-now-on-android/ |title=A Dark Room is now on Android! |publisher=Blog.doublespeakgames.com |date=2016-07-11 |accessdate=2016-09-20}} ==Gameplay== The game begins with the player awakening in a cold, dark room after a mysterious event. Initially, the player can only light and tend a fire in the room. As the game progresses, the player gains the abilities to collect resources, interact with strangers, start a village, and explore the world. As the game progresses, the type and quantity of resources and exploration available increases.{{cite web|last1=Alexander|first1=Leigh|title=A Dark Room's unique journey from the web to iOS|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/212230/A_Dark_Rooms_unique_journey_from_the_web_to_iOS.php|website=Gamasutra|accessdate=19 October 2015}} According to ''[[The New Yorker]]'', "What follows is a strange hybrid, part mystery story and part smartphone productivity software...the game evokes the simplest text-based computer games of the nineteen-seventies while stimulating a very modern impulse to constantly check and recheck one's phone. It's like a puzzle composed of deconstructed to-do lists." The site added, "You can begin to see a structure emerge from the fragments, but where that structure will lead you remains impossible to predict, and so the compulsion to keep pressing little word buttons grows stronger." ==Critical reception== {{Video game reviews | rev1 = ''[[TouchArcade]]'' | rev1Score = {{rating|4|5}}{{cite web |url=https://toucharcade.com/2014/06/03/a-dark-room-review/ |title='A Dark Room' Review – Surprising Things Can Be Found In The Dark |last=Musgrave |first=Shaun |website=[[TouchArcade]] |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=8 June 2018}} }} ''[[TouchArcade]]'' gave the game a rating of 4 out of 5, writing, "It's a strange little thing, to be sure, but I'd definitely recommend A Dark Room to people who appreciate off-beat RPGs, fans of experience-driven games, or really anyone looking for something a little bit different from usual." Slide to Play rated it 3 out of 4, commenting, "It may not seem like much at first, but if you stick around long enough, it's easy to fall under A Dark Room's spell."{{cite web|url=http://www.slidetoplay.com/review/a-dark-room-review/ |title=A Dark Room Review |publisher=Slide to Play |date=2016-04-15 |accessdate=2016-09-20}} 148Apps gave the game 3 out of 5, writing, "''A Dark Room'' may have plenty of longevity and may be genuinely intriguing, but its interface feels undeveloped in its iOS iteration."{{cite web|author=Our Review by Lee Hamlet on March 31st, 2014 |url=http://www.148apps.com/reviews/dark-room-review/ |title=A Dark Room Review |publisher=148Apps |date=2014-03-31 |accessdate=2016-09-20}} ''[[The New Yorker]]'' explained, "When ''A Dark Room'' was first released on [[iPhone]], at the end of 2013, the game was listed in a number of Best of the Year lists, including those published by [[Forbes]], [[Paste (magazine)|Paste]], and the gaming site, [[Giant Bomb]]." The app "rocketed to the most-downloaded spot in the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]]'s games section in April and stayed there throughout the month". [[Engadget]] praised the game's surprise ending, writing that "...it's definitely worth the time it takes to find it."{{cite web|last1=Wehner|first1=Mike|title=You should spend some serious time in A Dark Room|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/04/28/you-should-spend-some-serious-time-in-a-dark-room/ |website=Engadget |accessdate=19 October 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://adarkroom.doublespeakgames.com/}} * [http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/212230/A_Dark_Rooms_unique_journey_from_the_web_to_iOS.php GamaSutra] * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/01/a-dark-room-iphone-game_n_5241335.html Huffington Post] * [http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2014/05/21/a_dark_room_the_cormac_mccarthy_of_text_based_iphone_games.html Slate] * {{Metacritic video game|id=ios/a-dark-room}} {{portal bar|video games|2010s}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dark Room}} [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Alien invasions in video games]] [[Category:Browser games]] [[Category:Commercial video games with freely available source code]] [[Category:iOS games]] [[Category:Incremental games]] [[Category:2010s interactive fiction]] [[Category:Online games]] [[Category:Post-apocalyptic video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:Video games with textual graphics]]

{{Infobox album | name = American V: A Hundred Highways | type = studio | artist = [[Johnny Cash]] | cover = JohnnyCash-AmericanV.jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|2006|07|04|mf=yes}} | recorded = May 2003–August 2003 | venue = | studio = Cash Cabin Studio
{{small|([[Hendersonville, Tennessee|Hendersonville, TN]])}}
Akadamie Mathematique of Philosophical Sound Research
{{small|([[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles, CA]])}} | genre = {{flat list| * [[folk music|Folk]] * [[Country blues|folk blues]] }} | length = 42:45 | language = [[English language|English]] | label = [[American Recordings (US)|American]] | producer = [[Rick Rubin]] | prev_title = [[Personal File]] | prev_year = 2006 | next_title = [[American VI: Ain't No Grave]] | next_year = 2010 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Johnny Cash discography#American Recordings|American series]] | type = studio | prev_title = [[Unearthed (Johnny Cash album)|Unearthed]] | prev_year = 2003 | title = American V: A Hundred Highways | year = 2006 | next_title = [[American VI: Ain't No Grave]] | next_year = 2010 }}{{Singles | name = American V: A Hundred Highways | type = studio | single1 = God's Gonna Cut You Down | single1date = November 2006 }} }} {{Album ratings |MC=82/100[https://www.metacritic.com/music/american-v-a-hundred-highways/johnny-cash mc] | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4|5}}[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r840458|pure_url=yes}} link] | rev2 = ''[[NME]]'' | rev2Score = 9/10 | rev3 = [[Robert Christgau]] | rev3Score = {{Rating-Christgau|hm2}}[http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?name=johnny+cash link]
{{Rating|3.5|5}}[http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cdrev/cash2-ble.php link] | rev4 = [[Pitchfork Media]] | rev4Score = 7.8/10[https://web.archive.org/web/20060808184650/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/37205/Johnny_Cash_American_Recordings_V_A_Hundred_Highways link] | rev5 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev5Score = {{Rating|4|5}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20060706141512/https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/10621325/review/10681037/american_v_a_hundred_highways link] | rev6 = [[Slant Magazine]] | rev6Score = {{Rating|5|5}}[https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/johnny-cash-american-v-a-hundred-highways link] |rev7=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |rev7score=A-[https://web.archive.org/web/20060831090512/https://ew.com/ew/article/review/music/0,6115,1207340_4_0_,00.html EW] |rev8=''[[The Guardian]]'' |rev8score={{rating|5|5}}[https://www.theguardian.com/music/2006/jun/18/19 the guardian] }} '''''American V: A Hundred Highways''''' is a studio album by [[Johnny Cash]]. It was released on July 4, 2006, by [[American Recordings (US)|American Recordings]]. As the title implies, it is the fifth entry in Cash's [[Johnny Cash discography#American Recordings|American series]]. Like its predecessors, the album is produced by [[Rick Rubin]]. It was Cash's first No. 1 album in 37 years.Thomson, G. (2011). ''The Resurrection of Johnny Cash: Hurt, Redemption, and American Recording'' Jawbone Press, p. 233. It was certified Gold on August 18, 2006, by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. ==Background== As with the other albums in the American series, the album includes covers, originals. The originals on this album are "I Came to Believe" and "Like the 309", the latter of which was the last song Cash wrote before passing away in 2003.[http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/Music/06/27/ew.mus.cash/ CNN.com - EW review: Johnny Cash's brilliant finale - Jun 27, 2006] Recorded on August 21, 2003, "Like the 309" was the next-to-last song Cash ever recorded; the last being "Engine One-Forty-Three" which was produced by [[John Carter Cash]] and released on the 2004 compilation album ''The Unbroken Circle: The Musical Heritage of the Carter Family''.Robert Hilburn, ''Johnny Cash: The Life''. (New York: Little, Brown & Co., 2013), p. 624 The album takes its name from a lyric on the track "Love's Been Good to Me" by [[Rod McKuen]]. ===Previous recordings=== Three songs on the album are updated versions of songs previously recorded by Cash. *"Help Me" was previously recorded by Cash for his 1973 album "[[The Gospel Road]]". *"I Came to Believe" was previously recorded by Cash in the 1980s during the recording sessions that would ultimately result in the posthumous 2014 release ''[[Out Among the Stars]]''. *"I'm Free from the Chain Gang Now" was previously recorded by Cash for his 1962 album ''[[The Sound of Johnny Cash]]''. ==Chart performance== ''American V: A Hundred Highways'' peaked at No. 1 one the US [[Billboard 200]] with 88,000 copies sold in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was Cash's first No. 1 album since 1969's ''[[At San Quentin|Johnny Cash at San Quentin]]''. ==Track listing== {{track listing | title1 = [[Help Me (Larry Gatlin song)|Help Me]] | writer1 = [[Larry Gatlin]] | length1 = 2:51 | title2 = [[God's Gonna Cut You Down]] | writer2 = Traditional | length2 = 2:38 | title3 = Like the 309 | writer3 = [[Johnny Cash]] | length3 = 4:35 | title4 = [[If You Could Read My Mind (song)|If You Could Read My Mind]] | writer4 = [[Gordon Lightfoot]] | length4 = 4:30 | title5 = Further on Up the Road | writer5 = [[Bruce Springsteen]] | length5 = 3:25 | title6 = On the Evening Train | writer6 = [[Hank Williams]] | length6 = 4:17 | title7 = I Came to Believe | writer7 = [[Johnny Cash]] | length7 = 3:44 | title8 = Love's Been Good to Me | writer8 = [[Rod McKuen]] | length8 = 3:18 | title9 = [[(I'd Be) A Legend in My Time|A Legend in My Time]] | writer9 = [[Don Gibson]] | length9 = 2:37 | title10 = Rose of My Heart | writer10 = [[Hugh Moffatt (singer)|Hugh Moffatt]] | length10 = 3:18 | title11 = [[Four Strong Winds]] | writer11 = [[Ian Tyson]] | length11 = 4:34 | title12 = I'm Free from the Chain Gang Now | writer12 = Lou Herscher, Saul Klein | length12 = 3:00 | total_length = 42:45 }} ==Personnel== Cash engineer [[David R. Ferguson|David "Fergie" Ferguson]] (assisted by Jimmy Tittle) and Rubin oversaw the completion of the recordings. Other musicians on the album include keyboardist [[Benmont Tench]] and guitarists [[Mike Campbell (musician)|Mike Campbell]], Smoky Hormel, [[Matt Sweeney]] and [[Jonny Polonsky]]. *Johnny Cash – vocal, guitar *Laura Cash – fiddle *Dennis Crouch – bass guitar *Smokey Hormel – guitar *Pat McLaughlin – guitar *Larry Perkins – guitar *[[Jonny Polonsky]] – guitar *[[Randy Scruggs]] – guitar *[[Marty Stuart]] – guitar *[[Benmont Tench]] – organ, piano, harpsichord *Pete Wade – guitar *[[Mac Wiseman]] – guitar *Martyn Atkins – photography *Christine Cano – art direction, design *[[John Carter Cash]] – executive producer *Lindsay Chase – production coordination *[[Greg Fidelman]] – mixing *Paul Figueroa – mixing assistant *Dan Leffler – mixing assistant *[[Vlado Meller]] – mastering *[[Rick Rubin]] – producer, liner notes *[[David Campbell (arranger/composer)|David Campbell]] - string arranger *Mark Santangelo – mastering assistant *Jimmy Tittle – assistant engineer ==Chart positions== {| class="wikitable" ! Chart (2006) ! Peak
position |- | U.S. ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums | align="center"| 1 |- | U.S. ''Billboard'' 200 | align="center"| 1 |- | Canadian Albums Chart | align="center"| 4 |} ==Certifications== revision.text:
{{for|the Irish street photographer|Arthur Fields (photographer)}} {{Infobox Person | name =Arthur Fields | image =File:ArthurFieldsSitting.jpg | caption = | birth_name =Abraham Finkelstein | birth_date = {{Birth date|1884|8|6}} | birth_place =[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1953|3|29|1884|8|6}} | death_place =[[Largo, Florida]] | death_cause = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | occupation = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Arthur Fields''' (August 6, 1884 – March 29, 1953) was an [[United States|American]] singer ([[baritone]]) and songwriter.
[[Image:GreyGull2071.jpg|thumb|[[Grey Gull Records|Grey Gull]] record from late 1921 featuring Arthur Fields singing ''Weep No More, My Mammy''.]] [[File:IFawDownAn'GoBoom.ogg|thumb|Arthur Fields performs I far Down An' Go Boom with his Assassinators (1929).]] <!--{|align=right |{{Listen |filename=Irving Berlin - Arthur Fields - Oh! How I Hate To Get Up In The Morning.ogg |title="Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning" |description=[[Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning]], sung by Arthur Fields in 1919. }} |}-->
==Biography== He was born '''Abraham Finkelstein''' in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], but grew up mainly in [[Utica, New York]]. He became a professional singer as a youngster. Around 1908, he toured with [[Guy Brother]]'s [[Minstrel Show]], and helped form a [[vaudeville]] act "Weston, Fields and Carroll".
His first hit as a songwriter was "On the Mississippi" (1912), which he wrote the music for with [[Harry Carroll]] and [[Ballard MacDonald]] supplied the lyrics. In 1914 he wrote the lyrics to "[[Aba Daba Honeymoon]]", which was revived for the 1950 M.G.M. film ''[[Two Weeks With Love]]'' and thus got a renewed popularity which brought Fields large royalty incomes during his last two years.
From 1914 onward, he recorded with many bands and for many labels and had a varied career in the recording industry. In 1918, he was popular for his performance of his "[[Hunting the Hun]]" war song. His 1919 recordings with bandleader [[Ford Dabney]] may be the very first recordings of a white singer backed by a black band. For a period Fields also formed a vocal trio with brothers [[Jack Kaufman|Jack]] and [[Irving Kaufman (singer)|Irving Kaufman]], billing themselves as "The Three Kaufields". Fields also often appeared on records under [[pseudonym]]s, for example as "Mr X." on [[Grey Gull Records]] and related labels. In 1926 he recorded with [[Oreste Migliaccio]] & His Queensland Orchestra.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mainspringpress.com/fields_BA.html|title=Edison Blue Amberol Cylinder Records - Arthur Fields Cylindeography|publisher=}}</ref> His last records were made in the early 1940s.
Among Field's most prolific partnerships was the one with band leader and pianist [[Fred Hall (musician)|Fred Hall]], with whom Fields made plenty of records and co-wrote several songs, often with comic titles like "The Shoes We Have Left Are All Right", "You're My Little Rhapsody in Blue", and "I Can't Sleep in the Movies Anymore". Hall and Fields also [[broadcasting|broadcast]] together as [[Rex Cole's Mountaineers]].
Retiring to [[Florida]] in 1946 he also worked in radio on [[WQVN|WKAT]] [[Miami]]. He suffered a stroke early in 1953 and was killed in a fire at Littlefield Nursing Home in [[Largo, Florida]] a little later the same year.<ref>[http://www.phonostalgia.com/death/fields.html Arthur Fields's death certificate]. Accessed 12 June 2013</ref>
==Selected songs== *"[[Hunting the Hun]]" *"[[Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning]]" *"[[Oui, Oui, Marie]]" *"[[Over There]]" *"[[Tom, Dick and Harry and Jack (Hurry Back)]]" *"The Shoes We Have Left Are All Right"
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category|Arthur Fields}} *{{IMDb name | id=1023221 | name=Arthur Fields}} *[http://www.gracyk.com/fields.shtml Arthur Fields online biography by Tim Gracyk] *[https://archive.org/details/ArthurFieldswiththePeerlessQuartet Song ''Any Old Place the Gang'' from ''archive.org''] *[http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?query=arthur+fields&queryType=%40attr+1%3D1 Arthur Fields cylinder recordings], from the [[Cylinder Preservation and Digitization Project]] at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] Library. * {{YouTube|2YL6s_Z91Fs}} * {{YouTube|bpeU08OJRtU}} {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Arvind Gaur |image=Indian theatre director Arvind Gaur.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|2|02|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Delhi]], India | occupation = [[Theatre director|Theatre Director]] | awards = [[Karmaveer Puraskaar]] Artistes 4 Change; Colour of Nation Award, 2005 | website = | spouse = Sangeeta Gaur | children = Kakoli Gaur, Saveree Gaur }} '''Arvind Gaur''' (अरविन्द गौड़) is an [[Indian theatre]] [[Theatre director|director]] known for innovative, socially and politically relevant plays in [[India]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.hindu.com/mp/2008/05/03/stories/2008050352620200.htm|title=Walking the causeway |author=Nandini Nair |date=3 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-09 |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |location=Chennai, India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/indian-journal-seeking-balance-india/2012/jun/10/its-theatre-calling-change-india/|title= Theatre is calling for change in India|author= Sonal Jaitly|date=10 June 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-18|publisher=Washington Times}}</ref> Gaur's plays are contemporary and thought-provoking, connecting intimate personal spheres of existence to larger social political issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=390124401563 |title=Livewire, uninterrupted |publisher=The Asian Age|accessdate=2010-05-08 |author=Vatsala Shrivastava|date=7 May 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeoutdelhi.net/theatre/theatre_details.asp?code=73&source=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231111239/http://www.timeoutdelhi.net/theatre/theatre_details.asp?code=73&source=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-12-31 |title=Brechtfast in Ballimaran |publisher=Time Out Delhi |accessdate=2008-10-09 }}</ref> His work deals with [[Internet censorship]], [[communalism]], [[caste]] issues, [[feudalism]], [[domestic violence]], [[crimes]] of [[State (polity)|state]], politics of power, [[violence]], [[injustice]], [[social discrimination]], [[marginalisation]], and [[racism]]. Arvind is the leader of Asmita, [[Delhi]]'s "most prolific theatre group",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeoutdelhi.net/theatre/theatre_details.asp?code=18&source=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231113505/http://www.timeoutdelhi.net/theatre/theatre_details.asp?code=18&source=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-12-31 |title=Super trouper |accessdate=2008-10-09 |author=Trisha Gupta }}</ref> and is an [[actor]] trainer, [[social activist]], [[street theatre]] worker and [[Storytelling|story teller]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/staging-narratives/302102/|title=Staging Narratives-Storytelling session for visually impaired children|author= Neelima Menon|date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-12-24 |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref>
Gaur was the recipient of a research fellowship awarded by the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)]] (1997–98). He was on the guest faculty of Delhi University for Theatre in education program for three years. He has conducted many theatre workshops and performed in colleges, institutions, universities and schools in India and abroad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunysb.edu/sb/wang/archives/fall2004/index.shtml|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805235840/http://www.sunysb.edu/sb/wang/archives/fall2004/index.shtml|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 August 2012|title=Untitled: A Solo Theatrical Performance by Lushin Dubey|author=Stony Brook University|date=14 October 2004|accessdate=2008-12-24|publisher=Charles B.Wang Center}}</ref>
He organizes theatre workshops for children<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/yw/2008/06/24/stories/2008062450470600.htm |title=Theatre tactics |author=Ishita Agarwal |date=24 June 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-09 |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> in schools and [[slums]] as well as [[street theatre]] performances on socio-political issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/It-is-not-just-a-play/Article1-593393.aspx|title=It is not just a play|author=Kinni Chowdhry |date=30 August 2010|accessdate=2010-08-31|publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main53.asp?filename=hub070712psychology.asp|title=‘Dialogue and debate from street plays inspire change’|author= Esha Vaish|date=7 July 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-18 |publisher=Tehelka}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-07-14/india/27913391_1_spread-awareness-timings-toi-initiative |title=Teach India strikes the right chord |date=14 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-09 |publisher=[[Times of India]]}}</ref> He has directed more than hundreds stage and street plays over 25 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/society/such-a-drama-queen/article19185172.ece|title=Such a drama queen |author= Malini Nair|date=2017-07-01|accessdate=2018-08-21|publisher=[[The Hindu]]}}</ref><ref name=treat>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2007/07/05/stories/2007070550770400.htm |title=A treat for the senses |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=2008-10-09 |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |location=Chennai, India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/a-toast-to-twenty/915411/0 |title=A Toast to Twenty|author=Jahnvi Sreedhar|date=23 Feb 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-13|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref>
== Personal life == He was born on 2 February 1963 in Delhi. Arvind’s father Shri Shiva Nandan Sharma (died on 16.04.09) was a Maths scholar and his mother Saraswati Devi is a housewife. He has one brother advocate Anil Gaur and three sisters: Shashi Prabha, late Mithlesh and Dr. Anita Gaur. His wife Dr. Sangeeta Gaur.
== Theatre career == After completing his schooling from Model School, Vivek Vihar in Delhi, he decided to study engineering in Electronic Communication. Later, he joined the Delhi Public Library drama group.<ref name=treat/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livehindustan.com/news/lifestyle/lifestylenews/article1-story-50-50-220628.html|title= जीवन का हर रंग है दिल्ली में-संस्कृति और तहजीब से लबरेज:अरविंद गौड़ |author= सत्यसिंधु|date= 2 March 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-12 |publisher=[livehindustan.com]}}</ref> In DPL He acted in and directed plays. Then he worked with slum kids and industrial labourers for some time and conducted workshops for them. His first street play was with Zakir Hussein College, called ''Videshi Aya''. It became very popular and he staged it around 200 schools. After this, his desire to express led him to journalism. He worked with the ''[[Navbharat Times]]'' newspaper as culture columnist for about four years.<ref name=treat/>
Watching plays, reading about them and writing about them is how his training in theatre started. He then shifted to [[Press Trust of India]] (PTI-TV). He was associated with TV serial ''Tana-Bana''. He was in charge of the research and programming there. All through his years with street theatre, print and television, Gaur had developed keen interest in direction. Finally, after devoting two years to PTI-TV, he felt the urge to switch to theatre completely.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theatrepasta.com/?p=113|title=Nalina Mittra catches up with Arvind Gaur to find out more about his journey|author=Theatre Pasta|date=8 October 2007 |accessdate=2008-12-24 |publisher=Theatre Magazine| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081227202855/http://theatrepasta.com/?p=113| archivedate= 27 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
=== Theatre journey === Arvind's debut play was [[Bhisham Sahni]]'s ''Hanoosh'' (February, 1993). He started his theatre journey with classics like ''[[Tughlaq]]'', ''Andha Yug'', ''[[Caligula (play)|Caligula]]'', ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'', etc.
He performed [[Girish Karnad]]'s ''[[Tughlaq]]'' in a small basement theatre (SRC). It was a huge success. His ''[[Tughlaq]]'' was selected as "the best play of the year 1994" by [[Sahitya Kala Parishad]]. He achieved greater heights during a decade in theatre. He trained actors in his own style. He trained them as a complete theatre person. Arvind Gaur also collaborated with theatre artists and groups specially in exploring a new language for solo performances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sites.google.com/site/asmitatheatre/Home/about-director|title=About Director-Arvind Gaur|author=Sites.google.com|accessdate=2008-12-30}}</ref>

=== Street plays === Gaur directed more than 40 [[street theatre]] performances on socio-political issues. He has always raised voice against any socio-political issue that effects the common public. He directed street plays like ''Corruption'', ''Garbage'', ''Road Rage'', and ''Dastak'' which is against the issue of eve teasing. His street plays are always thought-provoking and leave a huge mark on the mindset. He and his team performs socio-political street plays all across Delhi/NCR and the country. He is regarded as a man with a message who believes that change can start from society, if we wish to start the change.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newslaundry.com/2018/03/04/delhi-natak-alchemist-live-theatre-festival-nsd-mandi-house|title=Delhi,a Natak hub|author=Sashikala VP and Mihir Srivastava |publisher= News Laundry|accessdate=2018-08-21}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/magazine/leisure/story/20170918-arvind-gaur-asmita-25th-anniversary-india-against-corruption-movement-1039622-2017-09-08|title=Arvind Gaur explains how Asmita checks the system by not becoming a part of it|author=Sukant Deepak |publisher=[[India Today]]|accessdate=2017-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/road-shows/603614/2|title=Road Shows page-2|author=Dipanita Nath |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=2010-04-11}}</ref>
== Controversies == On May 2nd 2017, Theatre and film actor Shilpi Marwaha broke her 11-year long association with Asmita Theatre Group, alleging that Arun Gaur made "advances" towards her. He made advances, and the moment it happened, I said no and left. It started in February 2016 in Varanasi, when we were rehearsing for a play late at night. We were discussing a script when he tried to hold my hand and made advances towards me. I left immediately and thought he would not repeat this. But it happened again after five-six months. He would say, 'Yeh toh normal cheez hai, ismein galat kya hai?' After it happened for the first time, I did not go to Asmita for many days," she says[https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/actor-shilpi-marwaha-alleges-she-quit-asmita-theatre-group-after-founder-arvind-gaurs-advances-gaur-denies-charge/articleshow/58461003.cms]
== Awards == * Artists 4 Change [[Karmaveer Puraskaar]] Noble Laureates,2008 by iCONGO- Confederation of NGOs * Special Jury award for best play in experimentation with tradition the at International Solo Theatre Festival, [[Armenia]], 2004 * Colour of Nation Award at International Theatre Festival, Nizhnevartovsk, Russia for solo play ''Madhavi'' by [[Rashi Bunny]], 2005 * Radha Krishna Award for his contribution to Delhi’s art & culture, 2007 * Udhbhav Shikhar Samman in memory of Aacharya Vijyendra Sanathak [[विजयेन्द्र स्नातक]] ,2008 * Swar-Dhrohar award, 2007 * Special Honour Award by Delhi International Film festival 2015 <ref>{{cite news|title= Special Honour Award |url ==https://www.withoutabox.com/03film/03t_fin/03t_fin_fest_01over.php?festival_id==15669|accessdate=20 August 2018|agency= Delhi International Film festival|publisher=WithOutBox}}</ref> * PRAYUKTI SAMMAAN 2017 by [[Dainik Prayukti]] Hindi Daily at Constitution Club of India, New Delhi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prayukti Sammaan|url=http://www.univarta.com/news/india/story/827076.html|accessdate=30 Mar 2017|agency=UNI|publisher=UNI VARTA}}</ref>
== films/visual media == * Acted in [[Raanjhanaa]] as Guptaji directed by [[Aanand L. Rai]] <ref>{{cite news|title= Arvind Gaur IMDB |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5873798/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_i13|accessdate=20 August 2018|publisher=IMDB}}</ref> * Acted in [[JD (film)]] film directed by Shailendra Pandey with [[Govind Namdev]],[[Aman Verma]],[[Vedita Pratap Singh]] * acted in [[Gurgaon (film)]] * Acted in short film "Meri Jeevan ki Abhilasha" directed by Kriti Takkar which won second best fiction film in "Mise-en-Scene", the international student’s film festival,2010. * Assistant director, docu-film "In search of an ideology", director Prasanna for Doordarshan, [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)]]. * Worked with [[Press Trust of India]] (PTI-TV). * Acted in tele-film Dhabba directed by Green Oscar awardee [[Mike Pandey]], produced by [[Nafisa Ali]]. * Assistant director, docu-film Gokak (V. K. Gokak), director [[Prasanna]] for Sahitya Akademi, Delhi. * Research and scripting for TV serial Taana-Bana (1991–1992), produced by Press Trust of India.
== Translation and Scripting ==
===Translation=== *He translated [[Rabindranath Tagore]]'s Visarjan (Sacrifice), performed by the Darpana Theatre Group directed by Ujjwal Dave *Arvind Gaur translated Unsuni in Hindi; script and direction by [[Mallika Sarabhai]]
===Scripts=== He scripted plays like Untitled, Gandhari in search of light, I will not Cry, Bitter Chocolate (based on [[Pinki Virani]]'s book), ''[[Madhavi (play)|Madhavi]]'' solo play (based on [[Bhisham Sahni]]'s play) and many street plays for Asmita Theatre.
===Design=== Arvind Gaur designs lights for Naya Theatre group's major productions under the direction of Padma Shri [[Habib Tanvir]]. Gaur also assisted Shri Habib Tanvir during the Prithvi Theatre Festival. He designs lights for Agra Bazar [[Nazeer Akbarabadi]] 's poetry), Charandas Chor (his masterpiece play, [[Edinburgh Fringe]] Award), [[Asghar Wajahat]]’s Jis Lahore Nai Dekhya, Kamdeo ka Apna Basant Ritu ka Sapna (Habib Tanvir's adaptation of [[Shakespeare]]'s [[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]), Canadian-Indian playwright Rahul Varma's Zahreeli Hawa and Gaon ke naon Sasural, mor naon Damand.
===Major Actors=== Major cinema and theatre actors who trained under Arvind Gaur are [[Kangana Ranaut]], [[Deepak Dobriyal]], [[Manu Rishi]], [[Shilpa Shukla]], [[Rashi Bunny]], [[Aishveryaa Nidhi]],[[Tillotama Shome]], [[Imran Zahid]], [[Sheena Chohan]], [[Seema Azmi]],Ishwak Singh and Suraj Singh of [[Veere Di Wedding]] fame. [[Sonam Kapoor]] attended Gaur's acting workshop to learn the nuances of street theatre for her film [[Raanjhanaa]]. Other prominent theatre actors who worked with him are [[Mallika Sarabhai]], [[Piyush Mishra]], [[Lushin Dubey]], Bubbles Sabharwal, Ruth Sheard, Jaimini Kumar, etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sites.google.com/site/asmitatheatre/in-news/prominent-actor-s|title=Prominent Actor's who worked with Arvind Gaur|author=Sites.google.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312095541/http://sites.google.com/site/asmitatheatre/in-news/prominent-actor-s|archivedate=12 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref>
== Further reading == #"Arvind Gaur-A Decade in Theatre" by J.N. Kaushal (ex-Acting Chief, [[National School of Drama]], Repertory Company), published by ITI ([[International Theatre Institute]]), UNESCO, Indian Chapter #"Raising the curtain on theatre": Director Arvind Gaur reflects on why India needs a cultural policy by Seema Sindhu (Life Fires, September, 2007) #His Voice-"Ace Act", essay by Shekhar Chandran (New Women, Jan. 2008) #"The World of Theatre" by Ian Herbert, Nicole Leclercq (P-126) published by [[International Theatre Institute]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links ==
# [http://sites.google.com/site/asmitatheatre/in-news The good man of Delhi stage by Archana (2008-09-26) Mail-Today.] # [http://www.delhievents.com/2007/05/about-arvind-gaur-theatre-director.html Founder of Asmita Group, by Rohit Malik, Delhi Events (2008.12.30)] # [https://archive.is/20130110140936/http://www.aishveryaanidhi.com/inner/theatre_activity_2005.htm Gandhari, solo-act by Aishveryaa Nidhi] # [http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=63372. "All The World’s A Platform" by Shailaja Tripathi. Expressindia ,( 2003.09.17)] # [http://www.hindu.com/yw/2004/12/11/stories/2004121100490300.htm "Heal the wounds" by Rohini Ramakrishan,(2004/12/11), [[The Hindu]]] # [https://web.archive.org/web/20071130034416/http://html.lsrcollege.org/soc_dramsoc.asp Dramatics Society of Lady Shri Ram College] # [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2001/20011228/ncr2.htm "A plethora of problems afflicts Hindi theatre" Rana A Siddiqui, The Tribune.(2001.12.28)] # [https://web.archive.org/web/20071227144226/http://oneness.indiatimes.com/articleshow/1233372.cms "Mahesh Dattani's Final Solutions"Oneness Peace Festival,Hindu College,University of Delhi(2005.09.16)] # [http://www.hindu.com/mp/2008/01/12/stories/2008011252050200.htm "Play of rules-Arvind Gaur's street theatre-Hatke Bachke"Nandini Nair,The Hindu (2009.01.12)] # [https://web.archive.org/web/20040929061849/http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=72677 "Nobody’s Child-Bitter Chocolate" Express Features Service,The Indian Express (2004.01.08)] # [http://www.theotherfestival.com/2005/hfires.html"The Park’s The Other Festival"Onassis Awardee Manjula Padmanabhan's "Hidden fires"-The Museum Theatre,Chennai(2005.12.07) ] # https://web.archive.org/web/20130731014648/http://asmitatheatregroup.com/

{{Infobox video game |title = Bankshot Billiards 2 | image = Bankshotbilliards2cover.jpg |developer = [[PixelStorm]] |publisher = PixelStorm |released = November 22, 2005 |genre = [[Sports game|Sports]] [[Simulation game|simulation]] – [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]] |modes = [[Single player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Xbox 360]] ([[Xbox Live Arcade|XBLA]]) }} '''''Bankshot Billiards 2''''' is a [[Sports game|Sports]] [[Simulation game|simulation]] [[video game]] developed by [[PixelStorm]], as a sequel to [[Bankshot Billiards]]. It was released on November 22, 2005 on [[Xbox Live Arcade]]. The [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]] (pocket billiards) [[Computer simulation|simulator]] offers nine different game modes including [[nine-ball]], [[eight-ball]], [[Blackball (pool)|Euro eight-ball (blackball)]], [[Cutthroat (pool)|cutthroat]], [[Straight pool|14.1 continuous (straight pool)]], [[three-ball]], [[trick shot]]s, [[Speed pool|"Time Trial" (speed pool)]], and [[Golf (pool)|golf]]. It offers a wide range of graphic customization including table style, felt color, wood grain, ball set, and cue stick.
Support for the [[Xbox Live Vision Camera]] was added on September 20, 2006.
On December 4, 2007, ''Bankshot Billiards 2'' was declared an "[[Xbox Live Arcade#Pricing and releases|XBLA Hit]]" and received a reduction in price.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xblarcade.com/node/1465 |title=XBLA Hits Arrives with Dash Update December 4th |publisher=XBLArcade.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080221023014/http://www.xblarcade.com/node/1465 |archivedate=2008-02-21 |df= }}</ref>
== Multiplayer mode== ''Bankshot Billiards 2'' offers multiplayer play. Two players can play against each other via [[Xbox Live]] or on the same console.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://marketplace.xbox.com/en-US/Product/Bankshot-Billiards-2/66acd000-77fe-1000-9115-d802584107ec?cid=search''Bankshot Billiards 2'' Game Details]

revision.comment: /* Contents */ Corrected the page numbers on one feature in the comic (based on photos of first and last page).
revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> |title = Big Apple Comix |image = BigAppleComix.jpg |imagesize = |caption = ''Big Apple Comix'' (Sept. 1975). Cover art by [[Wally Wood]]. |schedule = |ongoing = |publisher = Big Apple Productions |date = September [[1975 in comics|1975]] |issues = 1 |writers = |artists = |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = Flo Steinberg |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = |altcat = |sort = Big Apple Comix |addpubcat# = |nonUS = }} '''''Big Apple Comix''''' is an early independent comic book published by [[Flo Steinberg]] in 1975. A historically important link between [[underground comix]] and what would later be called [[alternative comics]], this 36-page, 6{{fraction|3|4}}" × 9{{fraction|3|4}}" hybrid with glossy color covers and black-and-white interiors contains 11 sometimes sexually frank stories by such mainstream creators as [[Neal Adams]], [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]], [[Denny O'Neil]], [[Herb Trimpe]], [[Al Williamson]], and [[Wally Wood]]. Most of its stories revolve around [[New York City]] (colloquially known as "[[The Big Apple]]") during a particularly low ebb in the city's finances, crime situation, race relations, and infrastructure.
==Publication history== The [[one-shot (comics)|one-shot]] comic book was among a handful of 1960s-1970s precursors of the independently produced comics that first proliferated with the 1980s rise of "[[direct market]]" comic-book stores. Other such early links between [[underground comix]] and modern independents include [[Mike Friedrich]]'s ''[[Star Reach|Star*Reach]]'' and Wood's own ''[[witzend]]''. Critic Ken Jones, in a 1986 retrospective review, suggested that ''Big Apple Comix'' and [[Mark Evanier]]'s ''High Adventure'' may have been "the first true alternative comics".<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Jones|first=Ken|title=(review)|work= [[Amazing Heroes]]| number=89|date= February 15, 1986}} Cited in {{cite web|last=Dunchak |first=Lee |url=http://www.cosmiccomix.com/comics/Amazing%20heroes/b_index.htm |title=Buried Treasures of the Month |publisher=The Back Issue Bin (column), CosmicComix.con |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029033126/http://www.cosmiccomix.com/comics/Amazing%20heroes/b_index.htm |archivedate=October 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The comic featured writer-editor Goodwin displaying his [[cartoonist]] abilities; Adams and a fledgling [[Larry Hama]] sharing vertically split pages to parallel a street [[prostitute]] with a [[corporation|corporate]] [[secretary]] using sex to further her career; and Wood's story "My Word",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enjolrasworld.com/Richard%20Arndt/The%20Early%20Independents.htm | first=Richard J.|last=Arndt| title=''Big Apple Comix''|publisher= (entry), ''The Early Independents''|date=August 20, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716140648/http://www.enjolrasworld.com/Richard%20Arndt/The%20Early%20Independents.htm | archivedate=July 16, 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> a bitter parody of the [[Al Feldstein]]-scripted "My World" that Wood illustrated in [[EC Comics]]' ''[[Weird Science (comic)|Weird Science]]'' #22 (Dec. 1953). [[Linda Fite]] and [[John Verpoorten]] handled production work for the comic,{{cn|date=July 2017}} released with an [[Indicia (publishing)|indicia]] date of September 1975.
Steinberg printed 20,000 copies. [[Warren Publishing]], for which she ran its mail-order Captain Company division, allowed her to store inventory in the company's storage space. She recalled in 1984 that, "I did make my expenses and a little besides." Afterward, the men's magazine ''Cheri'' and the French magazine ''L'Echo'' each reprinted "My Word" and "Over & Under", with Steinberg passing along the reprint fees to the creators.<ref name=CI59>Steinberg in {{cite news| authorlink1=Jim Salicrup |first1=Jim|last1=Salicrup|first2=Dwight Jon|last2=Zimmerman| title=Fabulous Flo Steinberg| work=[[Comics Interview]] | issue=17 | date=November 1984|page=73|publisher=[[Fictioneer Books]]| location= New York City}}</ref>
==Contents== Source:<ref name=gcd>{{gcdb series|id=2285|title=Big Apple Comix}}</ref> *Front cover by [[Wally Wood]] *Foreword by [[Denny O'Neil]] (writer), [[Michele Robinson Brand]] (tentatively identified as artist) *"The Man Without A City" by Stu Schwartzberg (writer), [[Marie Severin]] (artist), pp. 3–5 *"Peep Shows" by [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]] (writer-artist), pp. 6–7 *"My Word" by Wally Wood (writer-artist), pp. 6-8 *"Can You Spot the New York Air Breather?" (no writer or illustrator credited), p. 11 *"The Tube" by Wally Wood (writer), [[Al Williamson]] (artist), pp. 12–14 *"A Nice Place To Visit, but..." by [[Linda Fite]], p. 15 *"Over & Under" by [[Neal Adams]] (artist, "Over"), [[Larry Hama]] (penciler, "Under") and [[Ralph Reese]] (inker "Under"); writer(s) uncertain, pp. 16–20 *"New York City: The Future" by [[Paul Kirchner]], p. 21 *"The Battery's Down" by [[Alan Weiss (comics)|Alan Weiss]], Howard Weiss, pp. 22–26 *"Lotsa Yox" by [[Herb Trimpe]] (pencils) and Wally Wood (inker), pp. 27–28 *"The Silent Minority" by [[Mike Ploog]], pp. 29–30 *"Token" by Herb Trimpe p. 31-34 *"Backword" by [[Flo Steinberg]] *Back cover by Ralph Reese
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205003638/http://splashpages.com/wood/woodlist/bigapple/bigapplecomix.html|archivedate=December 5, 2007|title= Wally Wood Showcase: ''Big Apple Comix''|publisher= Wally Wood Online Checklist at SplashPages.com|url= http://splashpages.com/wood/woodlist/bigapple/bigapplecomix.html|deadurl=yes}} Additional [https://web.archive.org/web/20071201151350/http://www.splashpages.com/ Archive of main page], December 1, 2007. *{{cite magazine|title=Special Fabulous Flo Steinberg Celebration|work=[[Comic Book Artist]]|number=18 |date=April 2002}}

revision.text:
{{redirect distinguish|Radio engineering|Radio-frequency engineering}} {{Infobox Occupation | name= Broadcast engineering | image= | caption= | type= [[profession]] | official_names= Broadcast engineer Broadcast [[design engineer]]
Broadcast [[systems engineering|systems engineer]]
Broadcast [[information technology|IT]] engineer
Broadcast [[information technology|IT]] [[systems engineering|systems engineer]]
Broadcast [[network engineer]]
Broadcast [[maintenance engineering|maintenance engineer]]
[[Video]] broadcast engineer
[[Television studio|TV studio]] broadcast engineer
[[Outside broadcasting|Outside broadcast]] engineer
[[Remote broadcast]] engineer | activity_sector= | competencies= Technical knowledge, Management skills, Professionalism | formation= see [[Broadcast engineering#Qualifications|professional requirements]] | employment_field= [[Radio]], [[television]], [[military]] | related_occupation= [[Engineering technologist|Technologist]], [[RF engineer]], [[engineering technician]], [[Technical operator]] | average_salary= }} '''Broadcast engineering''' is the field of [[electrical engineering]], and now to some extent [[computer engineering]] and [[information technology]], which deals with [[radio]] and [[television]] [[broadcasting]]. [[Audio engineering]] and [[RF engineering]] are also essential parts of broadcast engineering, being their own [[subset]]s of electrical engineering. Broadcast engineering involves both the [[Television studio|studio]] and [[transmitter]] aspects (the entire [[airchain]]), as well as [[remote broadcast]]s. Every [[Broadcast network|station]] has a broadcast [[engineer]], though one may now serve an entire station group in a city. In small [[media market]]s the engineer may work on a [[contract]] basis for one or more stations as needed.{{cite web|url=http://careerplanning.about.com/cs/occupations/p/broadcst_sound.htm |title=about.com - Broadcast Technician or Sound Engineering Technician: Career Information |publisher=Careerplanning.about.com |date=2010-11-08 |accessdate=2013-08-03}} ==Duties== Modern duties of a broadcast engineer include maintaining [[broadcast automation]] systems for the studio and [[automatic transmission system]]s for the transmitter [[physical plant|plant]]. There are also important duties regarding [[Radio masts and towers|radio tower]]s, which must be [[Preventive maintenance|maintain]]ed with proper [[lighting]] and [[painting]]. Occasionally a station's engineer must deal with [[complaint]]s of [[RF interference]], particularly after a station has made changes to its transmission facilities.{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oco/ocos109.htm |title=U.S. Department of Labor - Bureau of Labor Statistics - Broadcast and Sound Engineering Technicians and Radio Operators |publisher=Bls.gov |date=2012-03-29 |accessdate=2013-08-03}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skillset.org/tv/jobs/Studio_Broadcast/article_5477_1.asp |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070508172948/http://www.skillset.org/tv/jobs/Studio_Broadcast/article_5477_1.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-05-08 |title=Transmission Engineer - TV |publisher=skillset |date=2012-07-25 |accessdate=2013-08-03 }} ==Titles== Broadcast engineers may have varying titles depending on their level of [[expert]]ise and field specialty. Some widely used titles include: * Broadcast [[design engineer]] * Broadcast Integration Engineer * Broadcast [[systems engineering|systems engineer]] * Broadcast [[information technology|IT]] engineer * Broadcast [[information technology|IT]] [[systems engineering|systems engineer]] * Broadcast [[network engineer]] * Broadcast [[maintenance engineering|maintenance engineer]] * [[Video]] broadcast engineer * [[Television studio|TV studio]] broadcast engineer * [[Outside broadcasting|Outside broadcast]] engineer * [[Remote broadcast]] engineer ==Qualifications== Broadcast engineers may need to possess some or all of the following [[degree (education)|degree]]s, depending on the broadcast technical environment. If one of the formal qualifications is not present, a related degree or equivalent professional experience is desirable. * Degree in [[electrical engineering]] * Degree in [[electronic engineering]] * Degree in [[telecommunications engineering]] * Degree in [[computer engineering]] * Degree in [[management information system]] * Degree in broadcast technology ===Knowledge=== Broadcast engineers are generally required to have knowledge in the following areas, from conventional video broadcast systems to modern Information Technology: * Conventional broadcast ** Audio/Video [[instrumentation]] [[measurement]] ** [[Baseband]] [[video]] – standard / [[high-definition video|high-definition]] ** Broadcast studio [[acoustics]] ** [[Television studio]]s - broadcast [[video camera]]s and [[camera lens]]es ** [[Vision mixer|Production switcher]] (Video mixer) ** [[Mixing console|Audio mixer]] * Broadcast IT ** [[Video compression]] - [[DV25]], [[MPEG]], [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB]] or [[ATSC Standards|ATSC]] (or [[ISDB]]) ** Digital server [[playout]] technologies. - [[VDCP]], Louth, [[Harris Corporation|Harris]], control protocols ** [[Broadcast automation]] ** [[Disk storage]] – [[RAID]] / [[Network-attached storage|NAS]] / [[Storage area network|SAN]] technologies. ** Archives – [[Tape archive]]s or [[grid storage]] technologies. ** [[Computer networking]] ** [[Operating system]]s – [[Microsoft Windows]] / [[macOS]] / [[Linux]] / [[real-time operating system|RTOS]] ** [[Post production]] – [[video capture]] and [[non-linear editing system]]s (NLEs). *RF ** RF [[satellite uplink]]ing – High-powered amplifiers (HPA) ** RF [[communications satellite]] [[downlink]]ing – Band detection, [[carrier wave|carrier]] detection and [[integrated receiver/decoder|IRD]] tuning, etc. ** RF transmitter maintenance - IOT UHF transmitters, solid state VHF transmitters, solid state MF transmitters (AM radio), tube type VHF and MF transmitters. antennas, transmission line, high power filters, digital modulators, towers, tower lighting systems, backup generators. *Health and safety ** [[Occupational safety and health]] ** [[Firefighting|Fire suppression]] systems like [[1,1,1,2,3,3,3-Heptafluoropropane|FM 200]]. ** Basic [[structural engineering]] ** [[Radio frequency|RF]] hazard mitigation Above mentioned requirements vary from station to station. ==Digital engineering== The conversion to [[Digital data|digital]] broadcasting means broadcast engineers must now be well-versed in [[digital television]] and [[digital radio]], in addition to [[analog signal|analogue]] principles. New equipment from the transmitter to the [[radio antenna]] to the receiver may be encountered by engineers new to the field. Furthermore, modern techniques place a greater demand on an engineer's expertise, such as [[sharing]] [[broadcast tower]]s or [[radio antenna]]s among different stations ([[diplexing]]). [[Digital audio]] and [[digital video]] have revolutionized broadcast engineering in many respects.[http://mhp-interactive.org/tutorial/dtv-intro/dtv-transmission.shtml Interactive TV Web. ''Broadcast Engineering Basics''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505004655/http://mhp-interactive.org/tutorial/dtv-intro/dtv-transmission.shtml |date=May 5, 2007 }} Broadcast [[studio]]s and [[control room]]s are now already digital in large part, using [[non-linear editing]] and [[digital signal processing]] for what used to take a great deal of time or money, if it was even possible at all. [[Mixing console]]s for both [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]] and [[video]] are continuing to become more digital in the 2000s, as is the [[computer storage]] used to keep digital media [[libraries]]. [[Effects processing]] and [[TV graphics]] can now be realized much more easily and professionally as well. With the broadcast industry's shift to IP-based production and content delivery technology (sometimes referred as [[Broadcast 3.0]]) not only the production technology and workflows are changing, but also the requirements for broadcast engineers, which now include [[Information technology|IT]] and [[Internet Protocol|IP-networking]] knowhow.{{cite web|last1=Tony|first1=Orme|title=Understanding IP Networks|url=https://www.thebroadcastbridge.com/content/entry/6303/understanding-ip-networks-introduction|website=thebroadcastbridge.com|accessdate=5 May 2017}} Other devices used in broadcast engineering are [[telephone hybrid]]s, [[broadcast delay]]s, and [[dead air]] [[alarm]]s. See the [[glossary of broadcast engineering terms]] for further explanations. ==Engineering services== Broadcast stations often call upon outside engineering services for certain needs. For example, because [[structural engineering]] is generally not a direct part of broadcast engineering, [[tower]] companies usually [[design]] broadcast towers. Other companies specialize in both broadcast engineering and [[broadcast law]], which are both essential when making an application to a national [[broadcasting authority]] for a [[construction permit]] or [[broadcast license]]. This is especially critical in [[North America]], where stations bear the entire burden of proving that their proposed facilities will not cause interference and are the best use of the [[radio spectrum]]. Such companies now have special [[software]] that can map projected [[radio propagation]] and [[terrain shielding]], as well as [[lawyer]]s that will [[legal defense|defend]] the applications before the U.S. [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC), [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC), or the equivalent authorities in some other countries. ==Organizations== ===Brazil=== * SET – Sociedade Brasileira de Engenharia de Televisão e Telecomunicações, Brazilian Society of Television and Telecommunications Engineering, [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. ===Canada=== * Central Canada Broadcast Engineers (CCBE), [[Paris]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] {{cite web|url=http://www.ccbe.ca/ |title=Central Canada Broadcast Engineers (CCBE) |publisher=Ccbe.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} * Western Association of Broadcast Engineers (WABE), [[Calgary, Alberta]], Canada {{cite web|url=http://www.wabe.ca/ |title=WABE - The Western Association of Broadcast Engineers |publisher=Wabe.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} * IEEE Broadcast Technology Society (BTS) – Ottawa Section, Canada {{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/bts |title=IEEE Broadcast Technology Society |publisher=Ieee.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} ===Germany=== * FKTG – Fernseh- und Kinotechnische Gesellschaft e.V., [[Germany]]{{cite web |url=http://www.fktg.de/ |title=FKTG – Fernseh- und Kinotechnische Gesellschaft e.V. (Germany) |publisher=Fktg.de |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729053531/http://www.fktg.de/ |archivedate=2013-07-29 |df= }} ===India=== * Broadcast Engineering Society – BES (India), [[New Delhi]], India {{cite web|url=http://www.besindia.com/ |title=BES - Broadcast Engineering Society (India) |publisher=Besindia.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} ===Iran=== * Iran Broadcasting University [[Iran]], Tehran (plus two campuses in [[Qom]] and [[Dubai]]){{cite web |url=http://www.irib.ac.ir/persian/index.aspx?portalid=27 |title=IRIBU - Iran Broadcasting University (Iran) |publisher=IRIBU.ir |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523083122/http://www.irib.ac.ir/persian/index.aspx?portalid=27 |archivedate=2011-05-23 |df= }} ===Japan=== * Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers - [[Japan]] Council ===Mexico=== * Asociación Mexicana de Ingenieros y Técnicos en Radiodifusión A.C. (AMITRA), Delegación [[Benito Juárez]], [[México]] ===People's Republic of China (PRC)=== * China Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers, China[http://www.csmpte.com.cn/ China Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers, China(CSMPTE)] * IEEE Broadcast Technology Society (BTS) – [[Beijing]] Section, China[http://www.cie-china.org/ieee-beijing/ IEEE Broadcast Technology Society (BTS) - Beijing Section )] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029092126/http://www.cie-china.org/ieee-beijing/ |date=October 29, 2008 }} * IEEE Broadcast Technology Society (BTS) – [[Shanghai]] Section, China ===People's Republic of China – Hong Kong=== * Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers-(Hong Kong) Section, 電影電視工程師協會香港分會 [[Hong Kong]]{{cite web |url=http://www.smpte.org.hk/ |title=Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers-(Hong Kong) Section (SMPTE-HKG) |publisher=Smpte.org.hk |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219045708/http://www.smpte.org.hk/ |archivedate=2012-02-19 |df= }} * Society of Broadcast Engineers Hong Kong Chapter, 廣播工程師協會香港分會 [[Hong Kong]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sbe.org.hk/ |title=Society of Broadcast Engineers Hong Kong Chapter(SBE HK Chapter) |publisher=Sbe.org.hk |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} * Hong Kong Televisioners Association (HKTVA), 香港電視專業人員協會 Hong Kong{{cite web|url=http://www.hktva.org/ |title=Hong Kong Televisioners Association (HKTVA), Hong Kong |publisher=HKTVA |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} ===Philippines=== * Society of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians of the Philippines, Inc. (SBETP), [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]] ===Republic of China – Taiwan=== * IEEE Broadcast Technology Society (BTS) – [[Taipei]] Section ===South Korea=== * Korean Broadcast Engineers & Technicians Association (KOBETA), [[Seoul]], South Korea (ROK) ===Turkey=== * [[Chamber of Electrical Engineers of Turkey|Chamber of Electrical Engineers]] (EMO){{cite web|url=http://www.emo.org.tr/ |title=Hoş Geldiniz |publisher=EMO |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} (Joint chamber of electrical, electronics and biomedical engineers) ===United States=== In the [[United States]], many broadcast engineers belong to the [[Society of Broadcast Engineers]] (SBE).{{cite web|url=http://www.sbe.org/ |title=Society of Broadcast Engineers |publisher=Sbe.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03}} Some may also belong to the [[Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers]] (SMPTE),{{cite web |url=http://www.smpte.org/home |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070324042446/http://www.smpte.org/home |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-03-24 |title=Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers |publisher=Smpte.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-03 }} or to organizations of related fields, such as the [[Audio Engineering Society]] or [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]] (IEEE) [http://www.ieee.org/portal/site Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers ] - [[IEEE Broadcast Technology Society]] (BTS). For [[public radio]], the [[Association of Public Radio Engineers]] was created in late May 2006.[http://www.apre.us/ Association of Public Radio Engineers] home page ===Uruguay=== *[[ANDEBU]] – Asociación Nacional de Broadcasters Uruguayos, [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]] {{Expand list|date=May 2010}} ==Notable publications== *[http://www.broadcastbeat.com ''Broadcast Beat Magazine''] * ''[[Radio (magazine)|Radio]]'' (formerly ''[[BE Radio]]'') * ''[[Radio World]]'' * ''[[TV Technology]]'' * ''[[Broadcast Engineering (magazine)|Broadcast Engineering]]'' [defunct as of October 31, 2013]{{cite web|title=Magazine Update: Ceased, Suspended and Unable to Locate|url=http://magazinesptp.com/magazine-update-ceased-suspended-and-unable-to-locate/|work=Magazine Subscriptions|accessdate=26 October 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal|Television|Electronics|Engineering|Technology and applied sciences}} * [[Engineering technician]] * [[Technical operator]] * [[RF engineering]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Broadcast Engineering}} [[Category:Broadcast engineering| ]] [[Category:Computer engineering]] [[Category:Broadcasting occupations]] [[Category:Television terminology]] [[Category:Engineering disciplines]]

page.title: Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=January 2007}} {{Infobox video game | title = Carmen Sandiego:
The Secret of the Stolen Drums | image = Carmen Sandiego The Secret of the Stolen Drums.jpg | caption = PAL region cover art | developer = [[Artificial Mind and Movement]] | publisher = [[BAM! Entertainment]] | series = ''[[Carmen Sandiego (game series)|Carmen Sandiego]]'' | released = '''PlayStation 2'''
{{vgrelease|PAL|March 5, 2004}}{{vgrelease|NA|September 8, 2004}}'''GameCube''' & '''Xbox'''
{{vgrelease|PAL|March 5, 2004}}{{vgrelease|NA|September 13, 2004}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[Platformer]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[GameCube]] }} '''''Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums''''' is a {{vgy|2004}} [[video game]] of the [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] genre developed by [[Artificial Mind and Movement|A2M]] and published by [[BAM! Entertainment]] (European distribution being handled by [[Acclaim Entertainment]]) under license by [[The Learning Company]]. The game is based on the ''[[Carmen Sandiego]]'' series and features [[List of Carmen Sandiego characters#Cole Gannon|Cole Gannon]] along with [[List of Carmen Sandiego characters#Jules Argent|Jules Argent]], [[List of Carmen Sandiego characters#Shadow Hawkis|Shadow Hawkins]] and [[Chief (Carmen Sandiego)|the Chief]] of ''[[Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?#Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego? Treasures of Knowledge (2001)|Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego? Treasures of Knowledge]]''. This game is the first in the Carmen Sandiego series to give the player complete control of a character in a 3D world. The avatar, ACME agent Cole Gannon, must maneuver through multiple stages including a museum in [[New York City]], the beaches of [[New Zealand]], the palace in [[Bangkok]], [[Machu Picchu]], and five other exotic locations. The player fights against [[Carmen Sandiego (character)|Carmen]]'s robots and spirits to prevent her from stealing a beautiful diamond, the repository of all the knowledge of the nations. The game also features an in-game PDA system in which Shadow and Jules can send you "video mail". ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | title = Scores | PS2 = true | XBOX = true | NGC = true | na = true | GR_PS2 = 53.2% (13 reviews) {{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/915380.asp |title=Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums for PlayStation 2 |publisher=GameRankings |date=2004-09-08 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | GR_XBOX = 54.8% (5 reviews) {{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/919309.asp |title=Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums for Xbox |publisher=GameRankings |date=2004-09-13 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | GR_NGC = 56.7% (9 reviews) {{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/919613.asp |title=Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums for GameCube |publisher=GameRankings |date=2004-09-13 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | MC_PS2 = 53% (8 reviews) http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ps2/carmensandiegothesecret | MC_XBOX = 53% (7 reviews) {{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/xbx/carmensandiegothesecret |title=Search Reviews, Articles, People, Trailers and more at Metacritic |publisher=Metacritic.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | MC_NGC = 57% (9 reviews) {{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/cube/carmensandiegothesecret |title=Search Reviews, Articles, People, Trailers and more at Metacritic |publisher=Metacritic.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | GSpot_PS2 = 4.7 / 10 {{cite web|last=Navarro |first=Alex |url=http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/adventure/carmensandiego/review.html |title=Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums Review for PlayStation 2 |publisher=GameSpot |date=2004-09-08 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | GSpot_XBOX = 4.7 / 10 [https://archive.is/20130123222831/http://www.gamespot.com/xbox/adventure/carmensandiego/review.html ] | GSpot_NGC = 4.7 / 10 {{cite web|last=Navarro |first=Alex |url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/adventure/carmensandiego/review.html |title=Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums Review for GameCube |publisher=GameSpot |date=2004-09-13 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | IGN_PS2 = 5.6 / 10 {{cite web|author= Juan Castro |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/544/544660p1.html |title=Carmen Sandiego: Secret of the Stolen Drums - PlayStation 2 Review at IGN |publisher=Ps2.ign.com |date=2004-09-03 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} | IGN_XBOX = 5.6 / 10 {{cite web |author=Juan Castro |url=http://xbox.ign.com/articles/544/544662p1.html |title=Carmen Sandiego: Secret of the Stolen Drums - Xbox Review at IGN |publisher=Xbox.ign.com |date=2004-09-03 |accessdate=2010-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611221421/http://xbox.ign.com/articles/544/544662p1.html |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }} | IGN_NGC = 5.6 / 10 {{cite web|author= Juan Castro |url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/544/544644p1.html |title=Carmen Sandiego: Secret of the Stolen Drums - GameCube Review at IGN |publisher=Cube.ign.com |date=2004-09-03 |accessdate=2010-10-02}} }} The game received a mixed to negative response. It has a score of 57 on Metacritic for the Gamecube version [http://www.metacritic.com/game/gamecube/carmen-sandiego-the-secret-of-the-stolen-drums/critic-reviews] and 53 for the Xbox version.http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox/carmen-sandiego-the-secret-of-the-stolen-drums/critic-reviews A review for ''Carmen Sandiego: The Secret of the Stolen Drums'' was average. The closing comments were: "Is Carmen Sandiego: the Secret of the Stolen Drums worth your hard earned cash? Well, if you're a major fan of the television show and PC games, then no. If you're a gamer looking for sweet platforming action, then no...It may [however] entertain the kiddies for a while. Otherwise, simply rent it if you're curious." The game was given a rating of 5.6/10 (Mediocre).http://au.ign.com/articles/2004/09/03/carmen-sandiego-secret-of-the-stolen-drums-2?page=2 ==References== {{reflist}} {{Carmen Sandiego}} [[Category:2004 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:Carmen Sandiego games|Secret of the Stolen Drums]] [[Category:GameCube games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:Video games set in New York City]] [[Category:Video games set in New Zealand]] [[Category:Video games set in Thailand]] [[Category:Video games set in the United States]] [[Category:Video games set in San Francisco]] [[Category:Xbox games]] [[Category:Behaviour Interactive games]] {{action-adventure-videogame-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox flash series | image = | country = Spain | writer = | animator = | name = Cálico Electrónico: La Serie Flash | devise = Niko | voice-actor = Niko
Manel Muzas
Raúl Escolano
Karen Gutierrez
Kris Cembellín
Rafiki Cano
Santi Riscos
Sebastián Fábregas
Inocuo | launchdate = June 1, 2004 | alexa = 525,210 ({{as of|2013|1|25|alt=January 2013}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/calicoelectronico.com |title= Calicoelectronico.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] | accessdate= 2013-01-25 }} | website = {{URL|calicoelectronico.com|CalicoElectronico.com}} }} '''Cálico Electrónico: La Serie Flash''' was a series of Flash animations created by Nikodemo Animation in 2004. Set in 'Electronic City', its protagonist is a superhero far from the 'classic' hero profile: a short, chubby and not-powered Spanish man ('aspañol' as is called in the series). He risks his life time and again to save the city, using gadgets picked up at the Electronicaweb store. A chapter usually develops this way: a monster or a criminal attacks the city, Cálico tries to stop it (always unsuccessfully), goes to Electronicaweb, gets a new gadget and saves the day. Some "[[bloopers]]" are displayed during the credits, at the end of the episode. Although the series displays many humorous events, the episodes include much Spanish foul language, so viewer discretion is advised. Even though Cálico is the main character, many side series have run with it, featuring many characters from the original series. On June 4, 2009 Nikodemo Animation was shut down completely by its owners due to bankruptcy, which meant the cancellation of all in-progress Cálico Electrónico series' related content, including, but not limited to Rumbarola and animation series. ==Characters== ===Main=== * '''Cálico Electrónico''': Superhero, his name is '''Cálico Jack''' * Muzamán: Salesman of Electronicaweb & friend of Cálico Eléctrónico. * Ardorín: Nephew of '''Cálico Jack''', in the future is Cálico Lúbrico. ===Secondary=== * Perchita: Character inspired in '''[[Nobita]]''', he is a drug addict. * Donramon: Character inspired in '''[[Doraemon]]''', he is a dealer. * Alarico: Brother of Witerico and Chindasvinta. * Witerico: Brother of Alarico and Chindasvinta. * Chindasvinta: Sister of Witerico and Alarico. * Sombra Oscura: Character that is hidden from the enemies with his outfit. * Lobohombre: Character that transforms [[José María Aznar|Aznar]] when in contact with full moon * Chacho Migué: The gypsy salesman of ''Electroni Migué'' and ''Electronicaweb's'' direct competition. == Chapters == Calico's series was 3 seasons long, every one with 6 episodes, from 2004 to 2008. === Season 1 === * 1) ''El enemigo digital'' * 2) ''Los Ri-txars invasores'' * 3) ''El Lobombre'' * 4) ''Los niños mutantes de Sanildefonso'' * 5) ''Historia de amor'' * 6) ''Corretón'' === Season 2 === * 1) ''El fin de Cálico'' * 2) ''El fin de Cálico (Part II)'' * 3) ''El día que conocí a un super-héroe'' * 4) ''Cómo ser Cálico Electrónico'' * 5) ''Porque yo lo valgo...'' * 6) ''Cálico'' === Season 3 === * 1) ''Se ha escrito una escabechina'' * 2) ''Se ha escrito una escabechina (Part II)'' * 3) ''Los pelusos carambanales y otras boludeses'' * 4) ''Mira quién lucha'' * 5) ''El Ventri Loco'' * 6) ''La generación de la bola'' === Others === * ''Noche de paz 2005'' * ''Microsoft Developer Days'' * ''Capítulo especial de Navidad 2007'' * ''Cálico contra Xona-tan y los Ri-txars'' == Cápsulas/Capsules == From June 2008 until its end Nikodemos produced a weekly "capsule", or shorter than usual episodes. At the end of every capsule some character from the Cálico universe answered the questions sent by the series' fans by SMS. {| | valign="top" width=33% | * '''Cápsula 1''': "Culones" * '''Cápsula 2''': "Seres Superiores" * '''Cápsula 3''': "Semos Orinales" * '''Cápsula 4''': "REC II" * '''Cápsula 5''': "San Cayetano" * '''Cápsula 6''': "Dani no está" * '''Cápsula 7''': "El Increible Julc" * '''Cápsula 8''': "Héroe a distancia" * '''Cápsula 9''': "Pul Fittion" * '''Cápsula 10''': "¿Salen o no salen?" * '''Cápsula 11''': "El Sustituto" * '''Cápsula 12''': "El del Cabello Oscuro" * '''Cápsula 13''': "Horario Laboral" * '''Cápsula 14''': "Alaricoyo" * '''Cápsula 15''': "Despeñaperros M." * '''Cápsula 16''': "Jodidas Chuches" * '''Cápsula 17''': "Minijuegos" * '''Cápsula 18''': "El Reformao" * '''Cápsula 19''': "Special SMS" * '''Cápsula 20''': "Esto es Jalogüin" | valign="top" width=33% | * '''Cápsula 21''': "La nueva Electronicaweb" * '''Cápsula 22''': "Tiburón" * '''Cápsula 23''': "Animalicos" * '''Cápsula 24''': "Si yo fuera rico" * '''Cápsula 25''': "Mi gatete Don Ramon" * '''Cápsula 26''': "El Segurata" * '''Cápsula 27''': "Trabajo Navideño" * '''Cápsula 28''': "¡Es una Fieshta!" * '''Cápsula 29''': "La Güi" * '''Cápsula 30''': "Jodida Suerte" * '''Cápsula 31''': "La Tribu de los Chachos" * '''Cápsula 32''': "Evacuación Máxima" * '''Cápsula 33''': "Sus muertos vivientes" * '''Cápsula 34''': "El Conquistador" * '''Cápsula 35''': "Yelouston" * '''Cápsula 36''': "Carnavá Carnavá" * '''Cápsula 37''': "Guachmen" * '''Cápsula 38''': "Apagón" * '''Cápsula 39''': "El dia der papa" * '''Cápsula 40''': "No soy un Supermán" |} == Spin-offs == * Huérfanos Electrónicos * Los Niños Mutantes De Sanildefonso * Los Castings de Lobombre y Zombón == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.calicoelectronico.com }} * [http://www.electronicaweb.com/ Electronica Web website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Calico Electronico: La Serie Flash}} [[Category:Flash animated web series]] [[Category:Spanish animation]]
