revision.text:
"'''The [[Hanukkah|Chanukah]] Song'''" is a [[novelty song]] written by comedian [[Adam Sandler]] with ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' writers [[Lewis Morton]] and [[Ian Maxtone-Graham]] and originally performed by Sandler on ''Saturday Night Live''{{'}}s [[Weekend Update]] on December 3, 1994.{{cite web |title=SNL: 12/3/1994 (Roseanne/Green Day) - Weekend Update segment |publisher=SNL transcripts |date=3 December 1994 |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/94/94gupdate.phtml |accessdate=15 November 2011}} Sandler subsequently performed the song as part of his stand-up act, later updating it with new lyrics. All variations center on the theme of [[Judaism|Jewish]] children feeling alienated during the [[Christmas]] season, and Sandler's listing of Jewish celebrities (both real and fictional) as a way of sympathizing with their situation. ==Part I (1994)== {{Infobox song | name = The Chanukah Song | cover = Adam Sandler The Chanukah Song.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Adam Sandler]] | album = [[What the Hell Happened to Me?]] | released = 1995 | format = [[CD single]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Comedy music|Comedy]] | length = 3:44 | label = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]] | writer = Adam Sandler, [[Ian Maxtone-Graham]], [[Lewis Morton]] | producer = Adam Sandler, Brooks Arthur | prev_title = Lunchlady Land | prev_year = 1993 | next_title = Bleeps | next_year = 1996 }} This version appeared on Sandler's 1996 comedy album ''[[What the Hell Happened to Me?]]''. Persons referenced in "The Chanukah Song": *"You" (The hypothetical Jewish listener) *"Me" (Sandler himself) *[[David Lee Roth]] *[[James Caan (actor)|James Caan]] *[[Kirk Douglas]] *[[Dinah Shore]] (replaced in some performances with [[Pauly Shore]]) *[[Jon Bauman]] (Bowzer from [[Sha Na Na]]) *[[Fonzie|Arthur Fonzarelli]] ([[Henry Winkler]]) *[[Paul Newman]] (half-Jewish) *[[Goldie Hawn]] (half-Jewish) *[[James T. Kirk|Captain Kirk]] ([[William Shatner]]) *[[Spock]] ([[Leonard Nimoy]]) *[[Sam Schulman]] (the founding "owner of the [[Seattle SuperSonics|Seattle Super-Sonic-ah's]];" Schulman had sold it to the non-Jewish [[Barry Ackerley]] in 1985, nine years before the song was written. The situation would correct itself when Ackerley sold the team to another Jew, [[Howard Schultz]], in 2001.) *[[O. J. Simpson]] was declared as "not a Jew!" to great applause from the audience. *[[Rod Carew]] (Sandler erroneously claims "he converted;" Carew's wife and children are Jewish but he is not. Carew later contacted Sandler and said he found the song rather funny.)Charlton, James; Shatzkin, Mike; and Holtje, Stephen. ''The Ballplayers: Baseball's Ultimate Biographical Reference''. (New York: Arbor House/William Morrow, 1990), pp. 155-156. {{ISBN|0-87795-984-6}}. *[[Ann Landers]] ([[Eppie Lederer]]) *"[[Dear Abby]]" ([[Pauline Phillips]] at the time) *[[Harrison Ford]] (Sandler understated Ford's Jewish ancestry by saying he is only a quarter-Jewish; Ford's mother was Jewish).Jenkins, Gary (March 1999). Harrison Ford: Imperfect Hero. Kensington Books, 9–12. {{ISBN|0-8065-8016-X}}. *[[Ebenezer Scrooge]], described as not Jewish. *All of [[The Three Stooges]] (brothers [[Moe Howard|Moe]], [[Shemp Howard|Shemp]] and [[Curly Howard]]; [[Larry Fine]]; and [[Joe Besser]]) *[[Tom Cruise]], a [[Church of Scientology|Scientologist]], is mentioned in the song as not Jewish (Sandler jokes during the song that he “hear(s) his [[Talent agent|agent]] is” Jewish). Sandler also makes reference to the [[Carnegie Deli]], a famed Jewish restaurant in New York City (it closed in 2016), and mentions that "you don't need" two [[Christmas music|holiday songs]] that do not mention Christmas: "[[Deck the Halls]]," a celebration of the Pagan holiday of [[Yule]]; and "[[Jingle Bell Rock]]," a [[rockabilly]] winter song. During the final verse, performed originally on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' and on a [[Radio edit|radio cut]], Sandler sings the line "Drink your [[Gin and tonic|gin and tonic-ah]], but don't smoke [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuan-icah]]". On the uncut album version, and during various concert appearances, the line was changed to "Drink your [[Gin and tonic|gin and tonic-ah]], and smoke your [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuan-icah]]". The uncut version, despite the reference to marijuana, receives most radio airplay today; another radio edit skips completely over the gin and tonic/marijuana line altogether. ===Chart performance=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:20em;" | Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:2em;"| Year ! scope="col" colspan="3" | Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:13em;" | [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] |- !style="width:3em; font-size:90%"|[[Hot 100]]
{{cite web|title=Adam Sandler Album & Song Chart History|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=Adam Sandler|chart=Hot 100}}|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=December 31, 2011}} !style="width:3em; font-size:90%"|[[Adult Top 40|Adult Pop]]
{{cite web|title=Adam Sandler Album & Song Chart History|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=Adam Sandler|chart=Adult Pop Songs}}|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=December 31, 2011}} !style="width:3em; font-size:90%"|[[Alternative Songs|Mod. Rock]]
{{cite web|title=Adam Sandler Album & Song Chart History|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=Adam Sandler|chart=Alternative Songs}}|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} |- !scope="row"|"The Chanukah Song" |1996 | 80 || 28 || 25 | * [[RIAA]]: Gold{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=Adam+Sandler+#search_section|title=Gold & Platinum - RIAA|publisher=}} |- |} ==Part II (1999)== "The Chanukah Song, Part II" was recorded live at [[Brandeis University]] for Sandler's 1999 album ''[[Stan and Judy's Kid]]''. Persons referenced in "The Chanukah Song, Part II": *[[Winona Ryder]] (whose father is Jewish) *[[Ralph Lauren]] *[[Calvin Klein (fashion designer)|Calvin Klein]] *[[Louise Post]] and [[Nina Gordon]] of [[Veruca Salt (band)|Veruca Salt]] *[[Mike D (musician)|Michael "Mike D" Diamond]], [[Adam Yauch|Adam "MCA" Yauch]], and [[Ad-Rock|Adam "Ad-Rock" Horovitz]] of the [[Beastie Boys]] (Diamond and Yauch are Jewish, and Horovitz's father was Jewish) *[[Lenny Kravitz]] (half-Jewish) *[[Courtney Love]] (half-Jewish) (an error; neither of her parents was Jewish). *[[Harvey Keitel]] *[[Jennifer Beals]] (an error; Beals says she once wanted to be Jewish, but is not).{{cite web|url=http://www.thelwordonline.com/jbint_stepout04.shtml|title=Jennifer Beals Interview - Apr 2004|website=www.thelwordonline.com}} *[[Yasmine Bleeth]] (her father was Jewish) *[[Dustin Hoffman]] (referred to as Dustin Hoffmanica for the sake of rhyme) *[[O.J. Simpson]], "still not a Jew" *[[Don Messick]], voice actor of [[Scooby-Doo (character)|Scooby-Doo]] (This is an error as Messick was not Jewish; it may have been intentional simply because Doo rhymes with Jew) *[[Bob Dylan]], "was born a Jew, [[Slow Train Coming|then he wasn't]], but now he's back" (This is an error; as late as 2009 Dylan still identified as a Christian) *Robert Levine, husband of [[Mary Tyler Moore]] *[[Tiger Woods]] ("No, I'm not talkin' 'bout Tiger Woods".) *[[Happy Gilmore]], Sandler's title character in the 1996 film *[[Bruce Springsteen]], who "isn't Jewish", but "[Sandler's] mother thinks he is". Other [[popular culture|pop culture]] references include: [[Manischewitz]] wine, [[Hooked on Phonics]], [[Daryle Lamonica]], and [[Tijuana#Culture and contemporary life|Tijuana, Mexico]]. ==Part III (2002)== Included on the ''[[Eight Crazy Nights]]'' soundtrack featuring vocals from actor [[Rob Schneider]] and the children's choir The Drei-Dels. Persons referenced in "The Chanukah Song, Part III": *[[Ross Geller|Ross]] ([[David Schwimmer]]) and [[Phoebe Buffay|Phoebe]] ([[Lisa Kudrow]]) from ''[[Friends]]'' *[[David Lander]] (Squiggy) of ''[[Laverne & Shirley]]'' *[[Debra Messing]] *[[Melissa Gilbert]] (was adopted by a Jewish mother and raised in her faith) *[[Michael Landon]] (Landon, whose father was Jewish, grew up practicing Conservative Judaism and is buried in a Jewish cemetery.) *[[Jerry Lewis]] *[[Ben Stiller]] (Stiller's dad [[Jerry Stiller]] is Jewish, and mom [[Anne Meara]], who was of [[Irish Catholic]] background, converted to [[Judaism]]). *[[Jack Black]] (dad converted to Judaism, mom was born Jewish.) *[[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] ("converted to Judaism, but you guys can have him back!") *[[Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo|Deuce Bigalow]] ([[Rob Schneider]]—see note below) *[[Mickey Raphael]] (referenced by Schneider as "The guy in Willie Nelson's band who plays harmonica") *[[Osama bin Laden]], who is "not a big fan of the Jews". *[[Sarah Hughes]] (half-Jewish; "her mama's Jewish") *[[Harry Houdini]] *[[David Blaine]] (his mother was Jewish) *[[Gwyneth Paltrow]] (half-Jewish) *[[Jennifer Connelly]] (ethnically half-Jewish) *[[Lou Reed]] *[[Perry Farrell]] *[[Beck]] (maternal great-grandmother was Jewish) *[[Paula Abdul]] *[[Joey Ramone]] *[[Natalie Portman]] (as "Natalie Portmanika") Also, in an unedited version that Sandler sings at some of his comedy shows, he replaces the lyric "As for half-Jewish actors/[[Sean Penn]] is quite the great one/And [[Marlon Brando]]'s not a Jew at all/But it looks to me like he ate one" with "Gwyneth Paltrow's half-Jewish/But a full-time [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] winner/Jennifer Connelly's half-Jewish, too/And I'd like to put some more in her". While this version is not played on [[radio stations]], the [[music video]] shows a background screen showing a picture of Sandler licking his lips as the Jennifer Connelly lyric is sung, with shocked laughter coming from the audience. This version is hidden about four minutes after the edited version on the ''Eight Crazy Nights'' soundtrack. Although Sandler does not actually mention Schneider by name as part of the song, he mentions [[Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo|Deuce Bigalow]], a character played by Schneider, in the lyric, "but we can do it all night long, with [[Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo|Deuce Bigalow]]" (the "you can do it" line is also a reference to Schneider's recurring "townie" character that originally appeared in ''[[The Waterboy]]''). As Sandler mentions Bigelow, Schneider walks on stage, yells, "I'm Jewish!", and joins in for an abbreviated chorus. After the chorus, he sings a Jewish reference for the song (Mickey Raphael, see above), using an Elvis-esque vocal tic, to which Sandler seemingly ad libs "tiny Elvis, ladies and gentlemen, tiny Elvis!" (a reference to a Saturday Night Live skit Schneider performed with [[Nicolas Cage]]; and possibly also to [[Elvis Presley]], who was halakhically Jewish on account of his maternal great-great-grandmotherChandler, Adam (August 16, 2012). [http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/109613 "Elvis Presley: Jewish King of Rock"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203054632/http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/109613 |date=2013-12-03 }}. ''[[Tablet Magazine|Tablet]]''.) In the rehearsal version, Sandler then gives an aside of, "Schneider, I did not even know you were Jewish," to which Schneider replies, "I'm a Filipino Jew, in fact, I've gotta run home and light the first pig!" In the aired version, Schneider states, "I'm a Filipino Jew." When Sandler muses, "Filipino Jew?" Schneider responds, "There are four of us." He then puts on a blonde wig and joins the "Drei-dels," the backing chorus of children, to whom he is already similarly dressed. ==Part IV (2015)== Sandler first performed this version at a live Judd Apatow & Friends event, part of the New York Comedy Festival, in November 2015. Lyrics can be found at the Huffington Post link [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/adam-sandler-chanukah-hanukkah-song-part-4_56572747e4b079b2818a510d here]. Persons referenced in "The Chanukah Song Part IV": *[[Jesus]] *[[Olaf (Disney)|Olaf]] ([[Josh Gad]]) *[[Punky Brewster]] ([[Soleil Moon Frye]]) *[[Judd Apatow]] (in original performance only) *[[Scott Rudin]] *"Me" ([[Adam Sandler]]) *[[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]] *[[Stan Lee]] *[[Jake Gyllenhaal]] *The two guys who founded [[Google]] ([[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]]) *[[Adam Levine]] *[[Drake (rapper)|Drake]] *[[Seth Rogen]] *[[Bill Goldberg]] *[[Scarlett Johansson]] *[[Geddy Lee]] *[[Jonas Salk]] *[[Harry Potter]] ([[Daniel Radcliffe]]) *Jared from Subway ([[Jared Fogle]]) ("Goddammit, a Jew!") *[[Dr. Drew]] *[[Princess Leia]] ([[Carrie Fisher]]) *[[Elsa (Disney)|Queen Elsa from ''Frozen'']] ([[Idina Menzel]]) *[[David Beckham]] ("a quarter chosen") *[[Ron Jeremy]] ("fully Jewish") *[[Shia LaBeouf]] ("half a Jew") *Ice Cream's [[Ben & Jerry’s|Ben & Jerry]] ([[Ben Cohen (businessman)|Ben Cohen]] and [[Jerry Greenfield]]) ==Covers and spoofs== [[Jimmy Fallon]] impersonated [[Adam Sandler]] during a ''[[Celebrity Jeopardy! (Saturday Night Live)|Celebrity Jeopardy!]]'' sketch on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on October 24, 1998. In the sketch, Fallon, as Sandler, interrupts [[Will Ferrell]]'s [[Alex Trebek]] by playing guitar and singing (to the tune of the song's chorus and first few verses), "[[Robert De Niro]], [[Bela Lugosi]], [[Snuffleupagus]], and [[Parker Posey]]!" (Actually, De Niro, Lugosi and Posey were all raised [[Roman Catholic]]; [[Jerry Nelson]], the puppeteer who performed Snuffleupagus, was likewise not Jewish.) In 2004, Jewish-Australian hardcore punk band [[Yidcore]] covered it as "The Punk Rock Chanukah Song" in which they list Jews involved with punk music. This song was covered on two different occasions for the Broadway charity albums "Carols for a Cure." In 2006, the cast of Broadway's ''[[The Wedding Singer (musical)|The Wedding Singer]]'' sang the first installment of the song, led by [[Constantine Maroulis]], and featuring help from violinist [[Alicia Svigals]]. In 2013, the song was covered once again by the cast of ''[[Soul Doctor]]'', however this time, the lyrics covered Jewish Broadway personalities, including [[Mandy Patinkin]], [[Andrew Lippa]], [[Harvey Fierstein]], [[Harold Prince]] and others. These lyrics were written by the show's Shlomo actor Eric Anderson, who himself has been pointed out in the song as "not a Jew." In the season 3 ''[[The Office (US TV series)|The Office]]'' episode "[[Diwali (The Office)|Diwali]]", Michael Scott ([[Steve Carell]]) parodies Sandler by performing "The Diwali Song" during a Hindu [[Diwali]] festival.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qr25k3Dy7EU|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}} In 2008, [[Unitarian-Universalist]] Evan Austin performed a parody of this song called "[[The Chalica Song]]"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S5zoFZ0rNSE The Chalica Song], Youtube.com about the Unitarian-Universalist holiday of [[Chalica]]. Austin lists celebrities and historical persons who are "Unitarian-Universalists. Or Unitarians. Or Universalists. Or people with similar ideas." In 2009, Austin recorded "[[The (Second) Chalica Song]]" [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jb8FFCa6b4I The (Second) Chalica Song], Youtube.com with the same tune, but a new list of names. In 2009, a cover of the song by [[Neil Diamond]] was released on ''[[A Cherry Cherry Christmas]]''.[http://www.spinner.com/2009/09/29/neil-diamond-covers-adam-sandlers-chanukah-song/ Neil Diamond Covers Adam Sandler's 'Chanukah Song'], Steve Baltin, [[Spinner.com]], September 29th 2009 This version featured several changes in lyrics, including the change from "Tom Cruise isn't but I heard his agent is" to "Tom Cruise isn't, but [[Jesus Christ]] is". On a 2014 episode of ''[[Robot Chicken]]'', Sandler appears in a sketch on how to spell "Chanukah", singing a brief snippet of the song describing how [[Angelina Jolie]] is not a Jew. ==See also== *"[[The Thanksgiving Song]]" == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|KX5Z-HpHH9g|"The Hanukkah Song" by Adam Sandler, Saturday Night Live}} *[http://www.asandler.com/lyrics/hanukah.shtml Lyrics (Part I)] *[http://www.jewornotjew.com/ Jew or Not Jew] {{Hanukkah Footer}} {{Adam Sandler}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chanukah Song, The}} [[Category:Jewish comedy and humor]] [[Category:Holiday songs]] [[Category:Novelty songs]] [[Category:Hanukkah music]] [[Category:Adam Sandler songs]] [[Category:Neil Diamond songs]] [[Category:Saturday Night Live sketches]] [[Category:Songs written by Adam Sandler]] [[Category:1995 singles]] [[Category:Live singles]] [[Category:Sequel songs]] [[Category:1994 songs]] [[Category:Warner Bros. Records singles]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The X-Files'' (franchise)}} {{Infobox media franchise | title = ''The X-Files'' | image = The_X_Files_brand_logo.svg | caption = The brand logo of "The X Files", first introduced in November 5, 2000 on its [[The_X-Files_(season_8)|8th Season]] | origin = ''[[The X-Files]]'' | creator = [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] | films = ''[[The X-Files (film)|The X-Files]]''
''[[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]]'' | tv = ''The X-Files''
''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]''
''[[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|The Lone Gunmen]]'' | games = | books = [[The X-Files literature|Literature]] | comics = [[The X-Files (comics)|Comics]] | soundtracks = | music = [[Music of The X-Files|Music of ''The X-Files'']] }} '''''The X-Files''''' is an American [[science fiction]]–[[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] [[media franchise]] created by [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]]. The franchise generally focused on [[paranormal]] or unexplained happenings. The first franchise release—simply titled ''[[The X-Files]]''—debuted in September 1993 and ended in May 2002. The show was a hit for [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], and its characters and slogans (e.g., "The Truth Is Out There", "Trust No One", "I Want to Believe") became [[pop culture]] touchstones in the 1990s. 1996 saw the premiere of a second series set in the same universe but covering a storyline independent of the [[Mythology of The X-Files|X-Files mythology]], titled ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]''. In 1998, the first ''X-Files'' [[feature film]] titled ''[[The X-Files (film)|The X-Files]]'' was released, eventually grossing over $180 million. A spin-off—''[[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|The Lone Gunmen]]''—was released in 2001 and abruptly canceled. Six years after the initial television series was canceled, another film—''[[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]]''—was released. In January 2016, a [[The X-Files (season 10)|tenth season]] of ''The X-Files'' aired, featuring Carter as executive producer and writer, and starring [[David Duchovny]] and [[Gillian Anderson]].{{cite web |title=‘The X-Files’ Returns As Fox Event Series With Creator Chris Carter And Stars David Duchovny & Gillian Anderson |url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/x-files-returns-fox-event-series-david-duchovny-gillian-anderson-chris-carter-1201397721/ |publisher=Deadline.com |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=March 24, 2015 |accessdate=March 24, 2015}} An [[The X-Files (season 11)|eleventh season]] premiered in January 2018. In addition to film and television, ''The X-Files'' franchise has expanded into other media, including [[The X-Files literature|books]], [[video game]]s, and [[The X-Files (comics)|comic books]]. These supplements to the film and television series have resulted in significant development of the show's fictional universe and mythology. By May 2002, the franchise generated {{US$|1 billion|long=no}} in total revenue.{{cite web|last=McFarland|first=Melanie|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-85995347.html|title=Moody, mysterious `X-Files' gave us memorable moments.(The Seattle Times)|subscription=yes|publisher=[[Knight Ridder]]|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|date=May 17, 2002|accessdate=December 25, 2016}} == Television series == {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- ! rowspan="2"| Series !! colspan="11"|Television seasons !! rowspan="2"|Duration |- !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1993–94 United States network television schedule|1993/94]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1994–95 United States network television schedule|1994/95]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1995–96 United States network television schedule|1995/96]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1996–97 United States network television schedule|1996/97]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1997–98 United States network television schedule|1997/98]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1998–99 United States network television schedule|1998/99]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[1999–2000 United States network television schedule|1999/00]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[2000–01 United States network television schedule|2000/01]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[2001–02 United States network television schedule|2001/02]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[2015–16 United States network television schedule|2015/16]] !! style="width:2.5%;"|[[2017–18 United States network television schedule|2017/18]] |- style="text-align:center;" | style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| ''[[The X-Files]]'' || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 1)|1]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 2)|2]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 3)|3]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 4)|4]] ||colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 5)|5]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 6)|6]] ||colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 7)|7]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 8)|8]] ||colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 9)|9]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 10)|10]] || colspan="1" style="background:#98FB98; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 11)|11]]|| 1993–2002, 2016–2018 |- style="text-align:center;" | style="background:#FF5050; text-align:center;"| ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]'' || colspan="3" style="background:#ececec; color:gray; vertical-align:middle; text-align:center;" class="table-na"| || colspan="1" style="background:#FF5050; text-align:center;"| [[Millennium (season 1)|1]] || colspan="1" style="background:#FF5050; text-align:center;"| [[Millennium (season 2)|2]] || colspan="1" style="background:#FF5050; text-align:center;"| [[Millennium (season 3)|3]] || colspan="1" style="background:#FF5050; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 7)|Finale]] || colspan="4" style="background:#ececec; color:gray; vertical-align:middle; text-align:center;" class="table-na"| || 1996–99 |- style="text-align:center;" | style="background:#40E0D0; text-align:center;"| ''[[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|The Lone Gunmen]]'' || colspan="7" style="background:#ececec; color:gray; vertical-align:middle; text-align:center;" class="table-na"| || colspan="1" style="background:#40E0D0; text-align:center;"| [[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|1]] || colspan="1" style="background:#40E0D0; text-align:center;"| [[The X-Files (season 9)|Finale]] || colspan="2" style="background:#ececec; color:gray; vertical-align:middle; text-align:center;" class="table-na"| || 2001 |- |} ''[[The X-Files]]'', starring [[David Duchovny]] and [[Gillian Anderson]], first aired on September 10, 1993. Originally following the work of Special Agent [[Fox Mulder]], an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] investigator assigned to the [[X-files unit|X-Files]], a division tasked with the solving of cases for which there are no explanation. Special Agent [[Dana Scully]], a shrewd medical doctor, is assigned to debunk Mulder's work, though as the two continue to investigate the unexplained and the paranormal, her own faith is also tested. Scully later works alongside both [[John Doggett]] ([[Robert Patrick]]) and [[Monica Reyes]] ([[Annabeth Gish]]). ''The X-Files'' is generally divided into two classes of episodes, the first, "monster-of-the-week", or stand-alone episodes, and the second, [[Mythology of The X-Files|X-Files mythology]], which follows a [[Conspiracy (crime)|government conspiracy]] to hide the truth about the existence of [[Colonist (The X-Files)|extraterrestrial life]]. The series also stars [[Mitch Pileggi]] as Assistant Director [[Walter Skinner]], [[William B. Davis]] as [[The Smoking Man]] and [[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]] as [[Well-Manicured Man]]. ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]'', aired from 1996 to 1999, stars [[Lance Henriksen]] as [[Frank Black (character)|Frank Black]], a skilled criminal psychologist who could predict the actions of [[murderer]]s and [[serial killer]]s. Investigating the [[Crime|horrific crimes]], Black eventually became a [[consultant]] for the [[Millennium Group]], which believed that the world as we know it would come to an end at the beginning of the new millennium; a job which eventually leads to the demise of his wife, [[List of Millennium characters#Catherine Black|Catherine]] ([[Megan Gallagher]]). In the [[Millennium (season 3)|third season]], Black turns on the group and rejoins the FBI as a [[special agent]], working alongside Special Agent [[Emma Hollis]] ([[Klea Scott]]) to solve brutal crimes within the FBI's jurisdiction. ''[[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|The Lone Gunmen]]'', the third series in the ''X-Files'' franchise, follows the established characters of [[The Lone Gunmen#Richard Langly|Richard Langly]], [[The Lone Gunmen#Melvin Frohike|Melvin Frohike]] and [[The Lone Gunmen#John Fitzgerald Byers|John Fitzgerald Byers]] ([[Bruce Harwood]], [[Tom Braidwood]], and [[Dean Haglund]]), in their attempts to compile conspiracy-theorist magazine. Far more light-hearted than its predecessors, this series also stars [[Stephen Snedden]] as [[Jimmy Bond]], and [[Zuleikha Robinson]] as Yves Harlow. ''The X-Files'' has crossed over with both ''Millennium'' and ''The Lone Gunmen'', as well as ''[[The Simpsons]]'' (in the [[The Simpsons (season 8)|season 8]] episode "[[The Springfield Files]]"). {{Reflist|group=note}} ==Feature films== The first feature film, ''[[The X-Files (film)|The X-Files]]'', was released in 1998 in between the [[The X-Files (season 5)|fifth]] and [[The X-Files (season 6)|sixth season]]. It was intended to be a continuation of the season five finale "[[The End (The X-Files)|The End]]", but also be able to stand on its own. Season six opener "[[The Beginning (The X-Files)|The Beginning]]" picked up where the film left off. The majority of the film was shot in the break between the series' fourth and fifth seasons.{{cite video |people=[[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Carter, Chris]] and [[Rob Bowman (filmmaker)|Bowman, Rob]] |date=2005 |title=Audio Commentary for The X-Files: Fight the Future |medium= DVD |publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Home Entertainment]]}} The film follows the actions of [[Fox Mulder]] ([[David Duchovny]]) and [[Dana Scully]] ([[Gillian Anderson]]) after their dismissal from the [[X-files unit|X-Files]] division. Unlike the first film, the plot of ''[[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]]'' does not focus on the series' ongoing extraterrestrial-based "[[The X-Files#Mytharc episodes|mytharc]]" and instead works as a standalone [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]]–[[horror fiction|horror]] story. The film details ex-agents Mulder and Scully's search for a missing [[FBI agent]]. While [[Walter Skinner]] ([[Mitch Pileggi]]) makes a notable appearance, [[John Doggett]] ([[Robert Patrick]]) and [[Monica Reyes]] ([[Annabeth Gish]]) are absent from the film. During a July 2013 panel discussion at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]] hosted by ''TV Guide'', both Anderson and Duchovny expressed willingness to do a third feature film, but Carter was more reserved at the idea, stating, "You need a reason to get excited about going on and doing it again."{{cite news|title=A Very Special ''X-Files'' Reunion|newspaper=[[TV Guide]]|author=Keck, William|date=July 29, 2013|page=6}} {| class="wikitable" width=99% border="1" |- ! rowspan="2" | Film ! rowspan="2" | Release date ! colspan="3" | Box office revenue ! rowspan="2" | Director |- ! align="center" | United States ! align="center" | Other territories ! align="center" | Total |- | background-color:#98FB98;"| ''[[The X-Files (film)|The X-Files]]''{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=x-filesfightthefuture.htm |title=The X-Files (1998) |publisher=''Box Office Mojo'' | language= | accessdate=July 31, 2009}} | align="center"| June 19, 1998 | align="center"| $83,898,313 | align="center"| $105,278,110 | align="center"| $189,176,423 | align="center"| [[Rob Bowman (director)|Rob Bowman]] |- | background-color:#98FB98;"| ''[[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]]''{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2008/XFIL2.php |title=The X-Files: I Want to Believe |publisher=''The Numbers'' | language= | accessdate=July 31, 2009}} | align="center"| July 25, 2008 | align="center"| $20,982,478 | align="center"| $47,386,956 | align="center"| $68,369,434 | align="center"| [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] |} === Characters === ''The X-Files'' stars [[David Duchovny]], [[Gillian Anderson]], and [[Mitch Pileggi]], alongside [[Blythe Danner]], [[Martin Landau]], and [[William B. Davis]]. ''The X-Files: I Want to Believe'' stars Duchovny, Anderson, and Pileggi, alongside [[Amanda Peet]], [[Xzibit]], and [[Billy Connolly]]. == Merchandise == === Literature === {{main|The X-Files literature|The X-Files (comics)}} There are three series of novels based on ''The X-Files'' franchise, one based on each of the three shows. During the run of the television series ''[[The X-Files]]'', many books based on it were written and released, including novels based on episodes, a series of [[The X-Files (comics)|comic books]] from [[Topps Comics]], and many "official" and "unauthorized" non-fiction books. Some of the novels, which were published in both [[hardcover]] and [[Trade paperback (comics)|trade paperback]] editions, were adapted into [[audiobook]]s read by two of the series' stars, [[Gillian Anderson]] and [[Mitch Pileggi]]. Three ''X-Files'' books rose to the top-selling list over [[Europe]] and [[North America]]. These books were ''The Official Guide to The X-Files'', ''The Unofficial X-Files Companion'' and ''The X-Files Book of the Unexplained''.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/do-we-need-the-x-files-1345935.html |title=Do we need The X Files? |author=Lyttle, John |accessdate=June 26, 2004 |work=The Independent |date=May 6, 1996 | location=London}} series of licensed tie-in comics based on ''The X-Files'' were launched in 2004, by [[Topps Comics]],{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1995/03/06/1995-03-06__x__hits_spot_in_comics__too.html |title='X' HITS SPOT IN COMICS, TOO |author=Bianculli, David |date=March 6, 1995 |work=The New York Daily News |accessdate=July 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903064140/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1995/03/06/1995-03-06__x__hits_spot_in_comics__too.html |archivedate=September 3, 2009 |df= }} and in 2008 by the [[DC Comics]] imprint [[WildStorm]].{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=16784 |title=SPOTNITZ WANTS TO BELIEVE IN WILDSTORM'S "THE X-FILES SPECIAL" |author=Renaud, Jeffrey |date=June 12, 2008 |work=Comic Book Resources (CBR) |accessdate=July 27, 2009}} The [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Broadcasting Network]] publishes the official ''The X-Files Magazine''.O'Donnel, Maureen (June 25, 1997) "UFO lore alive in Chicago area". ''Chicago Sun-Times''. Retrieved on July 27, 2009. In total, five [[novel]]s have been based on ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]'', the first being a novelization of the [[Pilot (Millennium)|pilot episode]]. Some novels were also released as [[audiobook]]s read by actor [[Bill Smitrovich]]. In 2015, a [[Millennium (2015 comic book)|comic book adaptation]] of ''Millennium'' was released. === Toys and games === {{main|The X-Files merchandise}} ''[[The X-Files]]'' spawned a large number of spin-off products. [[The X-Files Collectible Card Game|''The X-Files'' Collectible Card Game]] was released in 1996, and an expansion pack was released in 1997.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamereport.com/tgr15/xfiles.html |title=X-Files CCG |author=Sarrett, Peter |year=1997 |work=Gamereport |accessdate=July 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111111031/http://www.gamereport.com/tgr15/xfiles.html |archivedate=January 11, 2009 |df= }} ''The X-Files'' has inspired three [[video game]]s. In 1998, ''[[The X-Files Game]]'' was released for the [[Personal computer|PC]] and [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] and a year later for the [[PlayStation]]. This game is set within the timeline of the [[List of The X-Files episodes|second or third season]] and follows Agent Craig Willmore in his search for the missing [[Fox Mulder]] and [[Dana Scully]].{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/TECH/computing/9806/19/xfiles.game/ |title=Computer X-Files: The game is out there |author=Baxter, Steve |date=June 19, 1998 |work=CNN |accessdate=July 27, 2009}} In 2000, [[Fox Interactive]] released ''[[The X-Files: Unrestricted Access]]'', a game-style database for Windows and Mac, which allowed users access to every case file.{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,282565,00.html |title=The X-Files: Unrestricted Access |author=Flaherty, Mike |date=April 10, 1998 |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=July 27, 2009}} Then, in 2004, ''[[The X-Files: Resist or Serve]]'' was released for the [[PlayStation 2]]. This game is an original story set in the [[The X-Files (season 7)|seventh season]] and allows the player control of both Mulder and Scully. Both games feature acting and voice work from members of the series' cast.{{cite news |url=http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/gadgets_and_gaming/article449465.ece |title=X-Files: Resist or Serve |author=McNamara, John |date=June 26, 2004 |work=Time Magazine |accessdate=July 27, 2009 | location=London}} A 12-inch [[Frank Black (character)|Frank Black]] figurine was issued by Sideshow in the same mold as ''The X-Files'' characters [[Fox Mulder]] and [[Dana Scully]] earlier. == Legacy == {{Main|1=List of accolades received by The X-Files|l1=List of accolades received by The X-Files|2=List of accolades received by Millennium|l2=Millennium}} ''The X-Files'' franchise has influenced many series over the years and became a television touchstone of the '90s. The first installment, ''The X-Files'', became an international hit and its two main actors, [[David Duchovny]] and [[Gillian Anderson]], became international [[sex symbol]]s.{{cite news| author= |date= May 18, 2001| title =Duchovny's droll appeal | work = BBC |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1337569.stm| accessdate = 9 July 2009}} Series such as ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'', ''[[Fringe (TV series)|Fringe]]'' and ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'' have cited ''The X-Files'' as a major influence.{{cite news |author=Wertheimer, Ron |title= Television Review: Caught in the Trap Of Science Run Amok |work=The New York Times |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940CE2DD133FF93BA35750C0A96F958260 |accessdate=July 27, 2009|date=March 8, 1999}}{{cite web |author=Millman, Joyce |title= T H E X • E • R • O • X F I L E S |work=Salon |url= http://www.salon.com/ent/tv/mill/1999/03/08mill.html |accessdate=July 27, 2009|date=March 8, 1999}}{{cite news |author=Bonin, Liane |title= NBC's only new hit may go to another network |work=Entertainment Weekly |url= http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85446,00.html |accessdate=July 27, 2009|date=August 14, 2000}}{{cite web |author=Rosen, Steven |title='Bones,' from the heap of tired ideas |work=Media Life Magazine |url= http://www.medialifemagazine.com/bones-from-the-heap-of-tired-ideas/ |accessdate=July 27, 2009|date=September 13, 2005}} The series has also topped ranking polls worldwide, but most notably in the [[English language|English-speaking world]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/top-cult-shows-40239.aspx |title=TV Guide Names the Top Cult Shows Ever |publisher=''[[TV Guide]]'' |accessdate=June 29, 2007 |date=July 27, 1998}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/04/26/entertainment/main507388.shtml |title=TV Guide Names Top 50 Shows|work=CBS News |date=April 26, 2002 |accessdate=July 29, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/completelist/0,,1651341,00.html|title=Complete List — The 100 Best TV Shows of All-TIME|work=Time Magazine|accessdate=July 27, 2009|date=September 6, 2007}}{{cite news|url= http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20036782_20037403_20037541_22,00.html|title=The Sci-Fi 25: The Genre's Best Since 1982|author=Pastorek, Whitney|work=Entertainment Weekly|year=2003|accessdate=July 27, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20207076_20207387_20207339,00.html|title=The New Classics: TV|author=|year=2008|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=July 27, 2009}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/mar/13/advertising.pressandpublishing|title=What the MediaDNA research found|author=|date=March 13, 2003|work=The Guardian|accessdate=July 23, 2009 | location=London}} Carter, Duchovny and Anderson celebrated the 20th anniversary of the series at a July 18, 2013, panel at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]] hosted by ''TV Guide''. During the discussion, Anderson discussed Scully's impact on female fans, relating that a number of women have informed her that they entered into careers in physics because of the character. The two other series in the franchise have, on the other hand, made less impact. ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]'', while well received by many critics,{{cite news |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/dvd/dvd_review.asp?ID=753 |title= Millennium: The Complete Third Season |first=Keith |last=Uhlich|date=September 9, 2005 |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |publisher=Slant Magazine}}{{cite news |url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/585/585120p1.html |title= Millennium: The Complete Second Season |first=Mike |last=Drucker|date=February 3, 2005 |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |publisher=IGN}}{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117911386.html? | title= Millennium |first=Jeremy |last=Gerard|date=October 21, 1996 |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |publisher=Variety Magazine}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,294919,00.html | title= SCARE GIVER |first=Ken |last=Tucker |date= November 8, 1996|accessdate=July 13, 2009 |publisher=Entertainment Weekly}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/20/tv/staring-into-the-heart-of-darkness.html | title= Staring Into the Heart of Darkness |first=Justine |last=Elias |date=October 20, 1996 |accessdate=July 12, 2009|publisher=The New York Times}} garnered criticism for the episodes being similar to each other in content and themes. [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'' magazine]] reviewer Jeremy Gerard, although his review was mostly favorable, criticized it for giving him the "nagging feeling" that it wanted to hurt him. Many reviewers noted the dark storylines of the series, which were constantly mentioned as a reason why the show never became widely popular.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/337699.stm |title=Chris Carter's ''Millennium'' a flop |first= |last= |date=May 7, 1999 |accessdate=July 12, 2009 |publisher=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/tech/feature/1999/09/09/virtual_season/index1.html |title= IT'S NOT THE END OF THE "MILLENNIUM," AFTER ALL |author=Wen, Howard |date= September 9, 1999 |work=Salon |accessdate=July 31, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1996/10/20/1996-10-20__x_traordinary_success_spawn.html |title='X'TRAORDINARY SUCCESS SPAWNS A DARK 'MILLENNIUM' |author=Slewinski, Christi |date=October 20, 1996 |work=The New York Daily News |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903073832/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1996/10/20/1996-10-20__x_traordinary_success_spawn.html |archivedate=September 3, 2009 |df= }} The spin-off, entitled ''[[The Lone Gunmen (TV series)|The Lone Gunmen]]'', lasted only one season due to declining viewership, although it too earned largely positive reviews.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,100560,00.html?iid=digg_share |title=The Goof Is Out There |first=James |last=Poniewozik |date=February 21, 2001 |accessdate=July 12, 2009 |publisher=''Time'' Magazine}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/05/business/media-creator-of-x-files-lifts-his-profile.html?pagewanted=2 |title=MEDIA; Creator of 'X-Files' Lifts His Profile |first=Jim |last=Rutenberg |date=March 5, 2001 |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |work=The New York Times}} On January 17, 2015, Fox confirmed that they were looking at the possibility of bringing ''The X-Files'' back. Fox chairman [[Dana Walden]] told reporters that "conversations so far have only been logistical and are in very early stages" and that the series would only go forward if Carter, Anderson, and Duchovny were all on board, and that it was a matter of ensuring all of their timetables are open.{{cite web |title=Fox Confirms ‘X-Files’ Reboot Talks, David Duchovny & Gillian Anderson To Return: Update |url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/x-files-reboot-talks-fox-1201352465/ |publisher=Deadline.com |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=January 17, 2015 |accessdate=January 18, 2015}} [[The X-Files (season 10)]] aired in January and February 2016. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051201031315/http://www.foxhome.com/xfilesportal/ The X-Files] at [http://www.foxhome.com/ Fox] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090707095742/http://www.xfiles.com/ The X-Files: I Want To Believe (2008) (Official Website)] {{Navboxes |title=''The X-Files'' universe |state=collapsed |list1= {{X-Files}} {{Millennium (TV series)}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:X-Files Franchise}} [[Category:The X-Files (franchise)| ]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:20th Century Fox franchises]] [[Category:Television programs adapted into comics]] [[Category:Television programs adapted into films]] [[Category:Television programs adapted into video games]]

revision.text:
{{for|the film production company|This Is That Productions}} {{Infobox Radio Show | show_name = This Is That | image = | imagesize = | caption = | format = [[Comedy]] | audio_format = [[Monaural|Monophonic]] | record_location = Vancouver, Canada | runtime = approx. 27 min. | creator = Pat Kelly
[[Peter Oldring]] | developer = | producer = [[Chris Kelly (composer)|Chris Kelly]] | executive_producer = | writer = | presenter = Pat Kelly
[[Peter Oldring]] | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = Canada | language = English | home_station = [[CBC Radio One]] | syndicates = | first_aired = July 2010 | last_aired = present | website = [http://www.cbc.ca/thisisthat This Is That] | podcast = [http://www.cbc.ca/thisisthat/podcasts/ CBC Podcasts] }} '''''This is That''''' is a [[news satire]] program broadcast on [[CBC Radio]], which airs comedic news stories presented in the style of a real CBC Radio public affairs program.Natasha Lederman, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/cbc-radio-satirical-show-this-is-that-sparks-as-much-outrage-as-laughs/article2069385/ CBC Radio satirical show 'This Is That' sparks as much outrage as laughs]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', June 21, 2011. Retrieved September 10, 2011. The program began as a summer replacement in 2010, returned in the summer of 2011, and was added to the regular schedule in the fall of 2011.[http://www.broadcastermagazine.com/news/cbc-radio-one-releases-fall-lineup/1000568783/ CBC Radio One Releases Fall Lineup]. ''Broadcaster'', September 6, 2011. Retrieved September 10, 2011. It is hosted by Pat Kelly and [[Peter Oldring]], and produced by [[Chris Kelly (composer)|Chris Kelly]]. The ''This Is That'' team have also produced comedy videos for the CBC's web comedy platform CBC Comedy.[https://www.cbc.ca/radio/thisisthat/after-9-seasons-this-is-that-says-farewell-seriously-1.4836456 "After 9 seasons, This Is That says farewell (seriously)"]. ''This Is That'', September 26, 2018. In September 2018, the ''This Is That'' team announced that its 13 new episodes in fall 2018 would be the show's final season. ==In the media== The program, whose style has been compared to ''[[The Onion]]'', has drawn phone calls from listeners who did not realize that they were listening to a comedy program and took the content seriously; Oldring and Kelly admit to having been surprised that listeners would be fooled.James Brotheridge, [http://www.prairiedogmag.com/archive/?id=886 It’s All Lies: Radio comedy goes newsy on ''This Is That'']. ''Prairie Dog Magazine'', August 11, 2011. Retrieved September 10, 2011. In June 2010, the ''[[National Post]]'' reported as fact that [[CTV television network|CTV]] purchased the set of the [[NBC]] series ''[[Friends]]'';{{cite news|last1=Vu|first1=Liem|title=CTV purchases the set from 'Friends' (well, according to 'This Is That')|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/06/29/ctv-purchases-the-set-from-friends/|accessdate=October 4, 2017|work=National Post|date=June 29, 2010|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130129125233/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/06/29/ctv-purchases-the-set-from-friends/|archivedate=January 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} this, however, was a satirical story by ''This Is That''.{{cite web|title=CTV Buys "Friends" Set|url=http://www.cbc.ca/thisisthat/main/2010/06/28/ctv-buys-friends-set/|website=This is That|publisher=CBC Radio|accessdate=October 4, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100711000333/http://www.cbc.ca/thisisthat/main/2010/06/28/ctv-buys-friends-set/|archivedate=July 11, 2010|date=June 28, 2010}} Two years later, esteemed Canadian journalist [[Robert Fulford (journalist)|Robert Fulford]] wrote an article for the ''National Post'' claiming that the show is "worth tuning in for".{{cite news|last1=Fulford|first1=Robert|title=This Is That is worth tuning in for|url=http://nationalpost.com/category/culture/2012/01/02/fulford-this-is-that-is-worth-tuning-in-for/|work=National Post|date=January 2, 2012|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130129162650/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2012/01/02/fulford-this-is-that-is-worth-tuning-in-for/|archivedate=January 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} Also in 2012, [[Public Radio International]] reported as fact a ''This Is That'' story that dogs in Montreal would have to know commands in both [[Charter of the French Language|English and French]] by law.[https://web.archive.org/web/20131003140042/http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/yourcommunity/2013/09/cbc-radio-show-strikes-again-with-ball-less-soccer-satire.html CBC Radio show strikes again with ball-less soccer satire], by John Bowman, at CBC.ca (via [[archive.org]]); published September 6, 2013; archived October 3, 2013; retrieved March 9, 2015{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/yourcommunity/2012/12/cbc-radio-bilingual-dog-parody-fools-the-internet.html|title=CBC Radio bilingual dog parody fools the internet|author=John Bowman|date=19 September 2013|publisher=[[Cbc.ca]]|accessdate=22 December 2014}} In early 2013, ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]]'' reported as fact a ''This Is That'' story in which a Canadian student "sued her university for failing to accommodate her allergies to cactuses, escalators, tall people, and mauve."[http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/01/14/harpers-magazine-reports-joke-story-as-real-blames-nefarious-cbc/ "Harper’s Magazine reports joke story as real, blames ‘nefarious CBC’"]. ''[[National Post]]'', January 14, 2013. In September of the same year, several media organizations, including ''[[USA Today]]'' and the ''[[Washington Times]]'', reported on a story about an U-11 organization that had decided to play [[soccer]] without a ball to remove competition from the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsgrid.com/soccer/entire-nation-of-canada-gloriously-punkd-by-networks-story-on-youth-soccer-no-ball-league/|title=CBC Radio Satire On 'No-Ball' Soccer League Fools Everyone - SportsGrid|publisher=Sportsgrid.com|accessdate=22 December 2014}} In 2014, Jonathan Jones at ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote an article analyzing the satire in their story about a New York artist creating invisible art and selling it for millions.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2014/sep/30/invisible-art-hoax-lana-newstrom-cbc|title=Invisible art: the gallery hoax that shows how much we hate the rich|author=Jonathan Jones|work=the Guardian|accessdate=22 December 2014}} ==Awards== The program has won three [[Canadian Comedy Awards]].[http://torontoist.com/2011/10/2011-canadian-comedy-award-winners/ 2011 Canadian Comedy Award Winners]. ''[[Torontoist]]'', October 18, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.canadiancomedy.ca/awardwinners.php?year=2013|title=Canadian Comedy Awards Festival - Award Winners|author=sifr4|publisher=Canadiancomedy.ca|accessdate=22 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222204311/http://www.canadiancomedy.ca/awardwinners.php?year=2013|archivedate=22 December 2014|df=}} Their comedy special "The Christmas Letter" won a gold medal in the category of Best Comedy Special at the 2014 New York Festivals International Radio Awards{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorkfestivals.com/worldsbestradio/2014/index.php?page=1&sAwardType=&sCategoriesType=&sCountryType=CANADA#res|title=New York Festivals|publisher=Newyorkfestivals.com|accessdate=22 December 2014}} and their fourth season won a bronze medal in the category of Best Regularly Scheduled Comedy Program at the same awards ceremony. At the [[6th Canadian Screen Awards]] in 2018, Oldring won the award for Best Actor in a Web Program or Series for his performance in the show's CBC Comedy video series.[http://calgaryherald.com/entertainment/local-arts/andrew-phung-peter-oldring-wynonna-earp-digital-secret-alberta-doc-win-canadian-screen-awards "Andrew Phung, Peter Oldring, Wynonna Earp Digital, Secret Alberta doc win Canadian Screen Awards"]. ''[[Calgary Herald]]'', March 9, 2018. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.cbc.ca/thisisthat/ Official site] [[Category:CBC Radio One programs]] [[Category:Canadian radio sketch shows]] [[Category:Satirical radio programmes]] [[Category:Canadian news parodies]] [[Category:2010 radio programme debuts]] [[Category:Canadian web series]] [[Category:2018 radio programme endings]]
